Take subway line 3 to Anguk station, exit 5. Airport bus NO.6011 stop is right behind. It takes about 1 hour and 20 minutes from Incheon Airport to here. From exit 5, continue straight. It took about 7 minutes to get here. Go to the right at "Jongno Tteokjip" There is a hotel building right in front! It took about 8 minutes to get here. Here's how to get to the hotel from Jongno 3-ga Station Exit 5. Come to the musical instrument store as shown in the video. Once you cross the traffic light You will see the hotel building in front of you, turn right It took about 5 minutes to get here. The hotel lobby has a cozy feel. Check-in time is 4:00 PM, and check-out time is 11:00 AM. We booked on Agoda for $220 for 3people. There are 2-bed deluxe and 2-bed premier apartments, and I will introduce you to the slightly more expensive premier apartment. To check in, insert and remove the room card. As soon as you enter, there is a shoe rack and  many storage cabinets on the right. Indoor slippers are not disposable items. There is a kitchen on the left There is a dining table for four. The kitchen is well equipped with gas stove,  oven, rice cooker, toaster, etc. Pots, frying pans, etc. are very clean. The refrigerator is very clean and very big.  However, they do not provide bottled water. I booked a room for 3 people,  but all kitchen utensils are provided for 4 people. It looks really clean and well organized. If you are looking for a clean residence hotel,  this is the perfect place. The sink is very clean. The microwave oven also has good performance. There is a dishwasher. The TV is big, but it doesn't have OTT service. There is a small study area.  It feels like a bit of a service area. The view was good.   You can see the park and the Blue House. A clean residence hotel in the heart of Seoul.  I highly recommend it. There are quite a few doors This is the second room on the right. There is a queen size bed,  a small desk and storage space. The bed mattress is a slightly firm style,  and the pillows and blankets are soft. Because it is a central heating and cooling system, there are control systems located throughout the system so that it can be adjusted. This is the innermost master room. There is a king size bed and a small TV. The bed was very clean A slightly firm mattress and soft blankets and pillows It was raining and gloomy,  but the view was pretty good. There is a large closet.  There is a safe and a bathrobe. There are hangers, hair dryers, etc. There is an empty space with nothing.  You can see Seoul Tower well from here. This is the master bedroom bathroom. Starting in April 2024, a law restricting the provision of disposable products will be enacted, banning the provision of disposable toothbrushes, toothpaste, razors, etc. The shower room is very waterproof. The bathtub is narrow and long.  There is absolutely no water stains or mold. The toilet is a bidet. There is regular shampoo,  body shampoo, and body lotion. There is no smell in the bathroom and it is very clean. The second bathroom has a washing machine.  However, there is no detergent. There are small stairs. The shower room is very well waterproofed. The toilet is a regular toilet. There is only regular shampoo and body shampoo here. The rooms are clean and of a decent quality,  so I recommend it. Now, shall we go and see the hotel facilities? Touch the sticker side of the room card,  select the desired floor, and press Enter. The gym is very large and well maintained. All the facilities are located on the second floor. The kids room has only one facility and is rather small. But, regardless, the kids love it so much. There is a swimming pool right next door.  The facilities are better than I thought. The small pool is about 60cm deep.  The adult pool is about 1.2m deep. There is a restaurant right next to the pool. As soon as you enter, there are drinks on the right. The restaurant is spacious. The variety of bread is a bit disappointing. It costs about $13.50 per person,  so the selection is limited. Carrot soup and seaweed soup and scrambled eggs Tomato pasta, rice and pork cutlet There are various sauces and seaweed. There's pineapple lettuce dressing green grapes and banana. There are bowls and plates and spoons for babies,  and there is cereal and milk. There aren't many varieties, but the taste was good. The tomato pasta and seaweed soup were especially delicious. "Onion" located at Exit 3 of Anguk Station A special place where you can eat Korean bread in a Hanok I recommend it for the atmosphere rather than the taste. More than 90% of our guests are foreign tourists. I recommend Jongro Bossam Alley. "Jongno 3-ga Janggun Oyster Bossam" You can enjoy bossam, gamjatang,  and oysters for 38,000 won. For more information, please check the description or comments below. Insadong's main street is just  to the left of the hotel's main entrance. There are lots of things to see and places to buy gifts. There are also unique brick sands. There's a fun convenience store on the second floor. Robots make lattes. Robots make ice cream. Robots make pizza. But you can cook Korean ramen yourself.  Hahahaha

We're leaving with "Loah" again today. Take exit 6 of Gwanghwamun Station on Line 5. Go straight ahead If you walk for about 2 minutes,  you will see the Seoul City Tour bus stop. If you get a chance, definitely ride it It took about 3 minutes to get to the "Koreana" hotel. There is an airport bus stop right in front of the hotel. The "GLOCALOCA" hotel is located  on the 19th and 20th floors of the "Koreana" hotel. The area surrounding the hotel is full of famous landmarks. I booked it for $105 per night for 2 people. If you come to the 20th floor,  you can check in at the welcome desk. Check-in is at 3pm and check-out is at 11am. As soon as you enter, there is a clean bathroom on the right. As soon as you enter, there are 4 disposable slippers and a hanger on the right. The shoes were thin but sturdy. There is a clean restroom on the left. 8 towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste are provided. There is also cleansing foam and hand wash! The shower room is clean, but there is no door in the shower booth. It was nice to have a middle door The first feeling was warm There is a very small refrigerator and fire extinguisher on the right. The fridge is a bit small. But the shared kitchen is very well-equipped. The TV is a smart TV that can watch Netflix, YouTube, etc. The table is wide so it is very useful The windows are double-glazed to block out noise. The view from the room overlooks the entire Gwanghwamun. Women's unique sensibility The bed is not of luxury hotel quality. It is ordinary. The mattress is moderately firm. It's a queen size bed. There was no crib guard here, so I pushed the bed against the wall. Overall, spacious room for the price, average bed But, good location for sightseeing and convenient transportation! But! I really like the shared kitchen. Let's take a look together! The communal kitchen is much nicer than I expected. Open 24 hours. Complimentary coffee, cocoa, ramen, cereal and milk. Air fryer, rice cooker, ice maker, microwave, electric range, dishwasher It's much neater than I thought. A water purifier, a clean sink, and various kitchen utensils are provided. You can taste Korean ramen to your heart's content. The feeling of space is also very cozy. There are two types of cereal available. There is also a communal kitchen on the 19th floor, but it is a bit smaller. All cooking facilities are well equipped. This is a shared refrigerator for guests. It is smaller than the 20th floor, but it is a good facility. You can see the shared office right away. There are spaces from single-person spaces to open spaces. In my opinion, I like the facilities more than the rooms. There is even a private meeting room. There are also public, clean restrooms here. The communal laundry room has a washing machine that you can use free of charge. There is one large washing machine and one dryer, and free detergent is also provided. There is no pool or gym, but I am satisfied. If you walk to the left of the hotel for about 6 minutes, you will reach Gwanghwamun Square. If you walk for about 10 more minutes, you will reach Gyeongbokgung Palace. You can take a free commemorative photo around 12:10 PM. It's great to rent a hanbok and wear it and take pretty pictures! For more information, please refer to the comments below ⬇️ This time, walk to the right of the hotel for about 3 minutes. If you walk 2 more minutes from here, you will reach Deoksugung Palace. Turn right first! If you go up for about 2 more minutes,  there is an elevator on the right. Press the "R" floor and come to the rooftop. This place offers a great view that is not well known. Go to Deoksugung Palace. It's about a 4-minute walk. As soon as you enter, you can see souvenirs at the "sarang" cafe on the right. It's pretty and of good quality. You can have a great time at Deoksugung Palace. Across from the hotel are City Hall Plaza and Cheonggyecheon Stream. You can have a good time here too This is not a famous restaurant, but it is a place worth experiencing. There is a “BBQ village” right next to Cheonggyecheon. Luckily, I was assigned a room. If you walk about 5 minutes from here towards Jongno, there is a famous restaurant called “Gwanghwamun Mijin.” There is usually a waiting time of about 20 minutes. Buckwheat soba and pork bossam are famous. Please leave comments and likes for our family

10 seconds from airport bus stop  & subway station to hotel Let's go with "Loah" today! Take subway lines 3 and 4  to Chungmuro ​​Station, exit 8. There is an airport bus stop immediately to the right. The hotel is right behind exit 8! It's so close that there's no need to explain. The hotel is located right in front of  airport bus stops 6001 and 6015. For more information, please see the  description or comments below. The hotel I will introduce to you today is suitable for  4 or more people (up to 6 people). The hotel information desk is small,  but neat and cozy. You will be given a total of 4 room card keys.  The elevator is very comfortable. The suite is located on the 10th floor and has two rooms. We were assigned room 1001. It was much wider than I thought We paid about $180 USD per night for 6 people. 3 double beds 2 bathrooms 2 refrigerators 2 tvs The toilet, shower room, and sink are all separate. This place provides amenities such as disposable  toothbrushes and toothpaste. There is a large spa facility. You can see Seoul Tower from your room. The bed is in good condition. There is a safe, a hanger, and slippers next to the bed. There is a sofa, a TV, and a refrigerator. You can get bottled water for free from the refrigerator next  to the front desk on the first floor. Here too, there is a refrigerator, hangers, slippers and a safe. It's a little disappointing that these aren't disposable slippers. We used the two double beds here by putting them  together to create a spacious space. The bed is very soft. You can see the Seoul Tower view  from anywhere in the room. Another bathroom features a luxurious bathtub. Likewise, the toilet, shower room, and faucet are separate. Amenities such as disposable toothbrushes  and toothpaste are also provided. The bathroom fixtures are luxurious Italian products. The luxurious and large bathtub is attractive. It's hard to find this level of quality for the price  of one night in a six-person hotel in the heart of Seoul. The spa facilities in particular were great for parties. It took an hour and a half to fill the spa halfway with water. If you have a family of 4 or more,  I would definitely recommend this place. Hotel facilities are minimal. The rooftop garden is great for a little healing. 24-hour free parking is available. But the biggest advantage - being close to the airport bus  and subway station is the best advantage. And there's a large convenience store right next door. There's a delicious hamburger steak  restaurant across the street. There is a Neoguri Ramyun restaurant  right in front of Exit 9 of Myeongdong Station. You can eat the ramen you want  with the toppings you want. The staff will be there to assist you. Namsangol Hanok Village is about  an 8-minute walk from the hotel. Myeongdong is one subway stop away or about a 15-minute walk away. How about the stayrak hotel I recommended today?  Was it helpful? If you found this helpful, please subscribe and like~

You can choose from a variety of Korean ramen  and add various toppings to try them out. About $3.70 per bowl "Loah" Mom's Mukbang There is a fish soup restaurant a minute's  walk from the hotel. Let's compare two places: Orakai Suites in Jongno and UH Flat the Seocho in Gangnam. The first hotel is Orakai Suites, located in the heart of Seoul. The hotel is about an 8-minute walk from Anguk Station or Jongno 5-ga Station on Line 3. It is located on Insadong Main Street, making it ideal for sightseeing. The rate is $200 per night for 3 people, including breakfast. This is a residence type with two bedrooms. The first impression of the room is classic. The kitchen was very clean and fully equipped. None of the hotels featured in the video were sponsored by the hotel. All were booked directly. This room is perfect for families as it is equipped with an oven, microwave, and dishwasher. And it was much cleaner than I expected. The second room has a queen size bed. There is a master bedroom inside. There is a king size bed. The bedding quality is mid-to-high level. The view is a general city view. The master bedroom bathroom has a bathtub. There is a separate shower room. The bathtub was a good size and very well cleaned. There is a washing machine and a drying rack in the second bathroom. However, there is no detergent. For more information, please refer to the description below⬇️ or the pinned comment. A gym and a kids' room are available. It was nice that there was a main pool, auxiliary pool, and jacuzzi. Breakfast has a limited variety. But the taste was okay. The room was newly renovated and very clean. On the left is a queen-size bed, and on the right is a single bed. You can see a lot of Voco's trademark colors, yellow and blue. The view from Seoul Tower was really beautiful. However, it looks small in the video, which is a shame.  In reality, it looks much bigger. There was a Britz Bluetooth speaker alarm clock on the table, and there were various charging terminals. The TV wasn't a smart TV The downside is that there are no outlets around the bed and partial lighting control is not available. There is a convenience store behind the elevator, so it is very convenient. There is a large cafe next to the elevator. There is a Burger King next to the large cafe. I think the water temperature is around 32 degrees. I didn't know that large tubes and beach balls were prohibited. Fortunately, it was before closing time so there was no one there, and the person in charge was understanding. There is a club lounge on the 18th floor. I thought the door was closed hahahaha After checking the room number, you can sit where you want. I like it so much, the atmosphere is so good I was able to eat light chocolate and cookies. Juice, soft drinks, coffee and tea are also available. The dessert was average. The coffee was delicious. But the view is still so beautiful. Oh!! But there's a twist Happy hour is from 5:30 PM to 8 PM! The taste of the food and the atmosphere are so good The quality of the food was higher than I expected. I was planning to eat a moderate amount here and then go out to eat, but the food here was so delicious that I ended up eating here. I was very satisfied with the lounge at the Voco Hotel. Open from 6:30 am to 10:30 am. Because there are many foreign guests, the menu features Korean bibimbap. Unfortunately, the bread is a bit disappointing. This hotel is supposedly the best in all of  South Korea, so I did a full review to see if that's true.This is the SHILLA Seoul! I do reviews out of 50 points in five categories.  The categories are; The Ambiance, The Room, The Dining, The Service, and the It-Factor. With that, let's go take a look around the hotel,  because I think you're gonna like this one... In my opinion, the best thing to do here at the SHILLA is the nature walk that they  have all throughout the property. It goes right next to the Seoul  fortress wall and is so serene. They're playing little music as  well, while you walk around. The SHILLA has an outdoor pool called the  Urban Island, which is one of the most visually striking and interesting parts of the hotel,  but unfortunately it is closed six months out of the year. They do, however, have an indoor pool  with a jacuzzi, cold, hot, and warm plunge pools, and a full nude spa, so you can make use of  all of those while the outdoor pool is closed. In the men's locker room they give you a full  outfit to change into, that you can actually take with you and use while you are here in  the pool, in the sauna, the spa, or in the gym. This property is part of the L hotels and resorts, Korea's largest chain of hotels. Specifically, it belongs to the chain's upscale portfolio, L City Hotel, a brand comprised of four-star properties targeted to business and leisure travelers. In this video, we will take a tour of the property and review whether it's the ideal hotel for your trip to Seoul. Let's head inside and start exploring from the ground floor. On the left side after the entrance, there are practical facilities like an ATM for quick withdrawals and an Angel and US coffee shop, which is also a brand owned by the Latte Group. It is conveniently accessible for a morning latte or a relaxing coffee or tea break after a busy day in the city. Now, let's make our way up to the second floor, home to the hotel's main lobby and front office and the central point of arrival for all guests. As you step out of the elevator, the hotel's front desk is located to the left. The elegantly designed lobby makes a strong first impression. Its aesthetics is best described as modern yet understated, embodying quiet luxury through refined materials and thoughtful layout. The space has abundant natural light which highlights the clean minimalist design and ample seating areas where guests can comfortably wait during check-in. The seamless integration of technology including selfch checkck-in kiosks and wallpass machine strikes a harmonious balance between efficiency and comfort. As for the check-in, the process was smooth and efficient with friendly front desk who made the experience welcoming. We were able to get our room quickly without any hassle, setting a positive tone for the stay. On the opposite side of the second floor, to the right of the elevator, you will find additional facilities. These include fully equipped conference rooms. Across these is a business corner arranged with desktop computers and a printer, providing guests with space to catch up on work, prepare business documents, or browse the web in a professional environment. You will then come across an autopay kiosk where you can conveniently pay for your parking before you leave. Just a few steps further is Saffron Restaurant. We didn't try this restaurant, but apparently it's known for its authentic and premium Middle Eastern halal menu. From the outside, the interior exudes a warm and refined ambiance enhanced by ornate Middle Eastern design. Also located on the second floor is a door that leads to a balcony. This open air terrace offers a refreshing escape with panoramic views of the busting city streets below. Surrounded by towering office buildings, it provides a unique vantage point to observe the vibrant urban life and a connection to the energy of the district without ever leaving the property. Let's make our way back down to the ground level using the escalator and explore a few more convenient features in the hotel. At the bottom of the escalator is a secondary entrance, a quieter back entryway that leads into a small counter which is set up for quick assistance or inquiries away from the bottle of the main lobby. There's also a set of brochure shelves neatly stocked with local travel guides, maps, and event flyers. Just a few steps away is a 7-Eleven convenience store open around the clock for anything you might need on the go. It's a practical touch to the hotel's features. Here's a look at the hotel directory where everything is clearly laid out by floor. Let's head to the third floor next to check out some wellness and utility facilities. Here we are on the third floor. In addition to the guest rooms located here, this level is also home to three key facilities that enhance guest experience. The first facility you will find here is the fitness center. Whether you're squeezing in a quick workout or sticking to your regular routine, this gym is well equipped. Complimentary bottled water, fresh towels, and gym mats are readily available to help you stay comfortable during your session. As for equipment, there's a solid variety to suit different fitness goals and workout styles. There is an adjustable bench that can be used for presses, rows, and other free weight exercises. Of course, there's a full rack of dumbbells next to it. In addition to free weights, the gym is equipped with multi-station machines that combine several resistance exercises into one compact unit, ideal if you're looking for a comprehensive workout. If you are focused on cardio exercises, there's a selection of modern machines, including treadmills, ellipticals, and stationary bikes, all of which looks to be well-maintained and positioned for easy access. Ab exercise benches are also available, great for your crunches, situps, leg raises, and core workouts. The gym also features a body belt vibrator, a throwback to old fitness trends, yet still appreciated by some for warm-ups or recovery sessions. The space is designed to be practical with floor to-seeiling mirrors that help create a sense of openness while also allowing you to monitor your form and posture during workouts. The fitness center is actually pretty solid, clean, well stocked, and has everything you need for a workout while traveling. After your workout, if you need to freshen up your gym clothes, you will find the coin laundry room conveniently located a few steps away. Honestly, this type of facility comes in really handy, especially if you're staying for more than a couple of nights. It has four sets of washers and tumble dryers, so even if a couple of machines are in use, there's still a good chance you'll find one free. They've put up clear step-by-step instructions on the wall, so even if you've never used a coin laundry setup before, you won't be confused. There's a detergent vending machine in case you didn't pack any, plus a bill and coin changer, which is handy if you're out of small change. There are even laundry baskets which saves you from juggling armfuls of clothes between machines. Once you have your laundry going, you don't have to just stand around waiting for the cycle to finish. Positioned just beside the laundry area is this multi-room. This nice little space features seating areas. Nothing too fancy, but comfortable enough to sit and relax while you wait. There's a microwave, probably meant for guests who bring along something to eat. A flat screen TV is mounted on the wall to catch some shows and help pass the time. You will also find several irons and steamers available if you want to press your freshly washed clothes or just give an outfit a quick refresh before heading out for a business meeting or a dinner date. Even with these selfservice options though, the hotel still offers traditional laundry service if you prefer to have it handled for you. Now, let's head up to our room. We are staying on the 21st floor. There are 435 rooms here with a variety to choose from standard rooms, superior rooms, deluxe family rooms, premier family rooms, and superior suites. All right, we are finally here. Room 2118. Tada. Let's have a room tour. Welcome to L City Hotel, Maongdong's superior double room. This is a 25 square meter room. As you step in, you will find a dedicated luggage rack to keep your bags off the floor. Mounted on the wall is a 43in flat screen TV that comes with an OTT box so you can enjoy Netflix streaming services. Just below it is a long console style desk that's both stylish and functional. Discreetly tucked inside is the mini refrigerator. There are also multiple drawers that hold all essential amenities, including the hotel compendium, the coffee and tea station, and an electric kettle. And of course, the surface of the console doubles as a working desk, giving you plenty of space to sit down with your laptop and other work necessities. It is topped with a sleek leather executive desk pad paired with a comfortable work chair accented by a modern study lamp and equipped with convenient multiport outlets. It is a good setup especially if you are working remotely. Across the working desk is a sitting corner. It features a stylish accent chair paired with a coffee table positioned right by the window. Next to it is the heart of the room, the double bed. This bed is from the Heon private brand, exclusively designed by Simmons in collaboration with Latte Hotels. It comes topped with four fluffy pillows, crisp white linens, and a cozy duvet. The sleep during our stay was comfortable and restful. It allowed us to wake up feeling refreshed, recharged, and ready for every new day of touring soul. A few steps from the bed, you'll find the closet laid out in the usual hotel fashion right next to the entrance door. Inside, there's a full set of hangers and two bathrooms. On the lower shelf, there's a digital safe for your valuables, hotel slippers, laundry bags, and even a fire extinguisher for safety. Now, let's head into the bathroom and see what we've got. First up, here's the shower area. It looks clean and spacious. Its beige colored tiles give it a warm, calming feel, almost like a spa. There's a large rain shower head overhead with hot and cold water option. The bath amenities are by Davines, a premium Italian brand known for its sustainable and high quality products. In compliance to a new environmental law, hotels in Korea no longer provide disposable toothbrushes or singleuse toiletries, so be sure to pack your own. Moving to the other side is the smart toilet. It features warm water, twin nozzles for both front and rear cleansing, and of course, heated seat. All in all, the bathroom is clean, functional, and quietly echocious. By the way, we booked this room for 300,8001 per night, taxes included. This rate covered the room accommodation, Wi-Fi, and access to all the hotels facilities. Just so you know, the room rate we booked didn't include breakfast. We wanted the flexibility to eat only when we had time instead of being tied to it every morning. But of course, we had to try it. So, let us show you what the breakfast spread looks like. This is Tea Cafe at the 27th floor. The restaurant's design is a blend of modern minimalism and natural warmth. Its floor to-seeiling windows offer panoramic views of Maongdong, while its neutral tones give a business-like and upscale vibe. Let's check out the spread. Over here is the hearty hot dish corner with beef bulgogi, baked fish, sausages, bacon, and fried rice. The live egg station is actually combined with a dim sum and noodle area, which can be a bit confusing. And to add to that, you'll also find items like fries, sauteed vegetables, and boiled eggs placed right in front. So, just be sure to take a look around before lining up since multiple dishes are being served from the same counter. This one here is the soup station topped neatly in its own corner. It offers three different types of soups every morning. Then there's a Korean side dish station, a full salad bar, and even a pasta station for those who want something more filling. There's also a cold cut section of salmon, assorted sliced meats, and cheeses, which fits right into the build your own light breakfast corner of the buffet. There's also a fruit selection with fresh sliced options along with a variety of yogurt choices. Right next is a cereal station offering a mix of classic favorites and healthier options. And here's the bread and pastry station with a nice variety of toasts, croissants, pies, and sweet pastries. To top it all off, there's a coffee and tea station and a beverage bar with a range of fresh fruit juices. Now that we've had a look at the spread, here are our thoughts. For the price of 30,0001 per person, the breakfast buffet at the hotel offers a decent variety with a well-rounded selection of options. However, the food quality is fairly average, which is what you will expect from a typical business style hotel buffet. And that pretty much wraps up our stay here at L City Hotel Mongdong. From the room to the breakfast and everything in between, we have given you a look at what you can expect. Now, before we go, here are our thoughts based on our stay experience. We are giving L City Hotel Maongdong Dong a score of 8.57. The property's location is perfect and it's spotless clean. While the hotel's facilities are modern and well-maintained, it lacks some leisure amenities commonly found in four-star properties worldwide, such as a swimming pool, a dedicated spa, or even a lobby lounge, which makes the price feel a bit on the higher side. The hotel could also benefit from improving the quality of its food in its allday dining outlet. All in all, the hotel offers a pleasant and satisfactory stay. A solid choice for your trip to Seoul. If you find this review helpful, please hit the like button, subscribe for more videos, and tap the bell icon for the latest updates. So, thank you so much for watching. Until then, let's keep exploring the world one trip at a time.

Before the MGallery opened, this was the only hotel with a view of the Han River in Korea. It's just one hotel, but it's actually a place where hotels from all over the world are gathered. Let's find out what it's like there, operated by the conglomerate SK, with a man. [Music] Hello, I'm Ttotto Man. In 1963, there were no proper resorts in Korea, so many US soldiers stationed in Korea went on vacation to Japan. To prevent this, the government took the lead in building the Walkerhill Hotel, the first all-resort hotel in Korea, at the foot of Achasan Mountain in Seoul Gwangjang-dong. Since it was initially built as a facility for US soldiers stationed in Korea, the hotel was named after Walter H. Walker, a hero of the Korean War and the first and 8th Army Commander. Then, in July 1978, the Sheraton Walkerhill Hotel, which is 18 stories above ground and 4 stories underground, which became the predecessor of today's Grand Walkerhill, opened. In 2004, the W Seoul Walkerhill, which became the predecessor of today's Vista Walkerhill, opened. The Sheraton and W Hotel signs, which are overseas brands, are  It was separated in 2017 and has since been operated under its own brands, Grand Walkerhill and Vista Walkerhill. In addition, the Douglas Hotel, built during the construction period, was also renovated and reopened in 2018, so there are now three hotels within the Walkerhill Hotel. The 1973 is bright and has a sense of weight. On the other hand, the similar Walkerhill has a wooden sculpture at the entrance and even media art above it, giving it the feel of a hip club. The hotel's predecessor was the W Hotel, the hippest of the Marriott brands, and that influence still remains. The Robin Hood's sign isn't high or grand, but it enlivens the atmosphere with colorful furniture and cushions that match the hip atmosphere. The check-in desk, on the other hand, looks rather ordinary. However, the biggest difference between the two hotels is the guest rooms. Let's take a look at the Walkerhill rooms with a similar hip feel first. First, I stayed in the Junior Corner Suite, the most popular hotel in the hotel. The use of White Tony from the floor to the furniture in the room is unique. It's interesting that the circular lights on the ceiling match the circular bed. The bed and carpet are in the same neutral color scheme, creating a perfect atmosphere. The colors are also great.  The unique, yet most appealing aspect of the Junior Suite is the view of the Han River from two directions. To the east, you can see the yet-to-be-opened Godeok Bridge, and to the west, the Olympic Bridge and Lotte Tower. You can also see the Gangbyeonbuk-ro Road, which is open and clear, below. This is one of the few five-star hotels in Korea with a clear view of the Han River. However, one thing that's disappointing is that there are small dots painted on the windows, so the view is not clear but rather hazy. I think this is to prevent people from seeing outside, but it's reallydisappointing. Furthermore, the blinds cannot be fully opened, and the upper part is always covered, reducing the view from 100 points to 80. At the head of the circular bed is a work table shaped like the bed. On top of it is an AI speaker, a CD player (hard to find these days), a box of office supplies, a coffee pot, and a UV sterilizer. The room is neatly decorated in white tones, but with so many things on it, it feels a bit cluttered. However, the drinks and snacks in the refrigerator are free, which is nice. Opposite the bed is a table and chair with a TV. However, it's not a smart TV, which is a must-have for staycations these days, so it's very difficult to watch Netflix or YouTube. The white and curved theme.  The bathroom, as expected from a guest room, has a curved design from the outside. The inside is neatly organized with white tiles. The bathtub is also a very large circular bathtub, and it takes a while to fill. It's great for kids to play in the water. Amenities are from L'Occitane, and the soap is from Donggu Ban. Himalayan pink salt is provided for the bathtub. Across from the bathtub is a dressing room with the best view I've ever seen in a hotel. The space is spacious, so you can hang a lot of clothes, and the robes and slippers are lovely. Looking at the view from the Junior Suite, you might think this is a good room. But let's take a look at the most basic room, the Deluxe Room. The Galaxy Room has two views: mountain and river. Let's start with the mountain view. As expected, it's all white. The 42-square-meter room is neither too small nor too large, but just right. The unique feature is the long sofa opposite the bed instead of a TV. I visited during the fall foliage season, and the mountain view was just as stunning as the river view. However, the window was fogged, making it less cool. The bathroom, while small, is clean and better than the Junior Suite.  It has a bathtub and is connected to the bedroom, so it does n't feel stuffy. The Philux River View has the same structure as the Mountain View, but it has a luxurious Han River view facing the Han River straight ahead. Let 's also take a look at the suites at Vista Walkerhill. The Studio Suite is one of the rooms with the most spacious view of Achasan Mountain. With an area of ​​70 square meters, it feels much more spacious than the Junior Suite. The bathroom has two sinks, and the view of Achasan Mountain is special. Of course, you can hide them with a curtain, so do n't worry. The Spot Suite is an incredible suite with a view of the Han River that can beat the spa. Only the Spot Suite has a gray floor and a dark-colored bathtub for enjoying the spa. The sink, shower booth, and toilet are open in the space where the spa is located. The living room and bedroom are separated by a wall on the inside. Even from the spacious living room, you can only enjoy the open Han River view. However, the bedroom is located on the inside and has no separate window. Finally, the Corner Suite is an upgraded version of the Junior Suite. It is located in the corner, but the room size is nearly twice that of the Junior Suite. The room is larger, so it has more windows, so the view is great. This is the best room I've ever seen. Think of it as an additional space with a dining table in front of the spacious living room compared to the Junior Suite. Now that you've seen the white, open Vista Walker room, how about a traditional Grand Walkerhill room? The most basic room at Grand Walkerhill, the Standard Room, has no view, but the Deluxe Room and above have views of the Han River or Achasan Mountain. Among them, the Deluxe and Club Deluxe are exactly the same room, but the Club Villa is located on the upper floor and has access to the club lounge. Let's take a look at the Club Deluxe Han River View Room that I stayed in. The room is 30 square meters, which is smaller than the basic room at a typical 5-star hotel. Looking out the window and seeing the bed in the center reminds me of the Deluxe Room at The Plaza near Seoul City Hall Station. Both are old hotels, so they seem to have structural limitations. However, the Deluxe Room at Grand Walkerhill doesn't overdo the design, giving it a comfortable feel. The padding-patterned walls give it the feel of a wooden mountain lodge. The side wall was hollowed out, giving it a simple yet transformed look.  I feel like they did their best within the available conditions, using sophisticated lighting without being excessive. While it's narrow, the Han River view is outstanding. However, Grand Walkerhill is further from the Han River than Vista Walkerhill, and there's a building in the middle, which is a bit disappointing. However, there's nothing to obstruct the view. The TV is mounted high on the wall to avoid obstructing the view. The bathroom is also small, so there's no separate space; you shower in the tub. Products from the American drugstore brand Kobiglow and Donggu bar soap are provided. Flaphyllax is also available, offering complimentary drinks and snacks in the refrigerator. If you want a room that's not cramped while eating at Grand Walkerhill, you should definitely choose a suite. There are several options, including the Deluxe Suite with a separate living room and bedroom, and the Family Deluxe Suite with two beds, perfect for families. Let 's take a closer look at the Vegan Suite, which I really liked for its clean concept and design. The "Vegan" in the Vegan Suite refers to the veganism we practice. The actual rooms are designed to exclude animal products and minimize environmental impact.  The lush greenery and the soft green carpet and furniture on the walls create a truly luxurious feel. Riding the cycle in one corner of the room actually generates electricity to light the room, so it might be a good idea to try it for some exercise. Grand Walkerhill is located further back than similar Walkerhills, so while the parking lot is visible, it's still a nice place to admire the beautiful scenery. The Royal Suite, the hotel's third-best room, is 110 square meters. Unlike the Galaxy Room, the Grand Walkerhill Suite has a very luxurious feel with its vibrant color tones and furniture textures. If you prefer a more refined and sophisticated style rather than a modern feel, the Grand Walkerhill Suite might be a better fit than the Vista Walkerhill. However, many of you will likely find the Grand Walkerhill's basic deluxe rooms disappointing, and I'm no exception. However, Grand Walkerhill has one room to spare: the Grand Club, a club lounge. If you book a room with a club fee included, the Grand Club on the 15th floor offers access to a high-end restaurant with a stunning view, thanks to the large windows that fill both sides. Enjoy the most beautiful views of the Han River and Mount Acha from the hotel.  There is a space where you can enjoy tea time, happy hour, and breakfast the next day, just like Yeonol Lounge. During tea time, a few simple cookies, fruit sandwiches, and coffee were provided. What surprised me was that the food served during the hour was of a very high standard. There were three kinds of desserts, including lamb trotters, mango shrimp, grilled chicken wings, and meatballs, as well as fruit and cake. With cheese and ham from the salad corner, I think the lounge food alone would be in the top five in Seoul. The breakfast had a variety of breads, and the salads and hams that would be good for breakfast were delicious. Although it was n't as good as the main breakfast buffet, I definitely enjoyed the meal. In fact, I would say that the lounge made up for the disappointment I had with the room. The space is great, and the food is well-composed and of excellent quality. If you want a food vacation, I highly recommend this hotel. On the other hand, Vista Walkerhill doesn't have a club lounge, but it has a secret weapon: Skyard. Skyard, created in collaboration with world-renowned plant hunter Seijun Nishiata, has an outdoor space with a view of the Han River decorated with various plants and sunbeds. Above all, there is a foot bath where you can soak your feet while spacing out.  It's a masterpiece. Similar to Walkerhill's herbivore plan, anyone can use it for free. How about the swimming pool and fitness center operated by Grand [Music]? The swimming pool and fitness center at Grand Walkerhill are located on the second basement level, so there's no view. The swimming pool has brick pillars, lattice doors on the ceiling, and mirrors, giving it a luxurious feel, typical of Grand Walkerhill. The depth is 1.2 meters and gradually deepens, which is nice. There's also a shallow children's pool on one side. The fitness center is equipped with Technogym equipment, but it's not very spacious and not very pretty, which is a bit disappointing. On the other hand, Vista Walkerhill's swimming pool has a high ceiling and floor-to-ceiling windows, offering an unobstructed view of the Han River. The photo was taken at dawn, so the outside view isn't included, but it 's definitely a great swimming pool for taking pictures and full of emotion. The fitness center is also spacious, has a variety of equipment, and has a great view. The Walkerhill Library on the second floor has over 3,000 domestic and international books, making it a great place to enjoy reading. The outdoor Forest Park, which children will enjoy, offers outdoor activities like camping. River Park, another seasonal outdoor swimming pool, is one of the few in Seoul with an international- standard main pool. It's a large outdoor pool that's not open yet. There 's also a tennis court that can be used with a reservation. Finally, let's take a look at the breakfast and other restaurants. Regardless of where you stay at Grand Walkerhill Vista Walker, breakfast is served at The Biffé located on the second floor of Grand Walkerhill. On weekends or when there are many guests, main dishes are also served at El Vino on the first floor of Vista Walkerhill. The food is the same, but the view is better at Del Vino, so it's better to use Del Vino. The main dishes are excellent. As Walkerhill operates various sigma restaurants, I think the service is excellent from the lounge to the breakfast. There are window seats for the initiation ceremony, but the view isn't particularly great, so there's no need to go early to make a reservation. The hotel's most famous sigma restaurant is Pizza Hill. It 's a building that's been around since the hotel was first built in 1963, and it's famous for its pizza while enjoying the view in the middle of the Achasan forest. You can also get a discount and order takeout from Bakery Pass Aju in the lobby of Grand Walkerhill. Honestly, it's a bit of a stretch to get a pizza at this price without the advantage of a good location. The pizza was delicious, but...  The value for money was really poor. In addition, Grand Walkerhill has the Korean restaurant Ondal, the Chinese restaurant Geumryong, and Vista Walkerhill has the Italian restaurant Del Vino, the Japanese restaurant Moaek, and the famous DJ and cocktail bar Rebar. Also worth checking out is Myeongwolgwan, a Korean beef charcoal grill restaurant with a traditional Korean house interior and an outdoor garden overlooking the Han River. So, what's your overall review of the Walkerhill Hotel? It's a well-balanced hotel that I'd love to visit often if it were a little closer. The hotel is located on the eastern edge of Seoul, inside Acha Mountain, so accessibility is quite limited. While there's a shuttle, it's also quite inconvenient to use public transportation. Having to drive a long way from downtown Seoul to enjoy a vacation is a bit of a burden. However, its distance from downtown Seoul can be an advantage. It occupies a vast site within Acha Mountain, so while it's far from the city center, the air is fresh and it feels like you're in a church. As it's located in a world-class hotel, there are plenty of walking and jogging trails here and there. It 's a great hotel for those who want to escape the city and heal but don't have the luxury of traveling far.  If I were to evaluate Vista Walkerhill on its own, it would be a hotel that offers clear river and mountain views and a modern feel, making it a great choice for younger travelers. However, the guestroom interior feels a bit dated. Chasing trends can feel out of place and outdated over time. Not only does it offer a swimming pool and fitness center, but it also boasts a unique Sky Lounge, a feature unique to Walkerhill. This hotel is also recommended for those who prioritize amenities. On the other hand, the standard guestrooms are a bit cramped and the interior design is disappointing. However, the club lounge's space and food quality are excellent, making it a great choice for vacationers. If you're planning to stay in a suite, the Grand Walkerhill Suite might be a better option than the similar Walkerhill in terms of design. I personally really like the balance between the guestrooms and amenities, so I'd love to visit again next spring for a vacation and some cherry blossom viewing. If today's video was helpful to you, please subscribe, like, and turn on notifications. I've been a man who's always leaving, always leaving. Thank you. [Music]

As summer approaches, many of you will be looking for a cool ocean view resort.   Let's find out with Ttottonam where that place, which boasts a hot ocean view that is called a children's paradise, is located. [Music] Hello.  I'm a man again, a man again . Geoje Belvedere, which we will introduce today, is located on Geoje Island, the second largest island in Korea and a place that preserves the beauty of other countries. Belvedere is an Italian word meaning beautiful view . As its name suggests, it is a place that embraces the quiet and beautiful Mongdol Beach of Geoje Island .  Everdeer can be found right after crossing the Geoga Bridge between Busan and Geoje Island .  In fact, some rooms offer not only an ocean view, but also a stunning view of the Geoga Bridge. Elbury was built with a total area of ​​27,800 pyeong and a total investment of 270 billion won .  A total of 400 rooms, this is a massive resort with an indoor recovery marina lounge with an infinity pool and the largest kids' facility in Gyeongnam .   The lobby was as large and spacious as the scale. It serves as a central hub connecting the two West and East buildings.  The ocean view beyond the window was spectacular, and unlike other ocean views, Belvedere's ocean view was unique to Geojedo Island in that it showed the sea, mountains, and islands all at once .  The rooms are largely divided into Deluxe Suite and Royal Premier Suite, and there are also Pororo-themed rooms that children will love.  The first room we will see is the upper-floor premium room called the Premier Suite. As soon as you enter the room, a spacious living room and kitchen appear. It is a clean resort room with a simple, uncomplicated feel that gives off a sense of the ocean.  Although cooking is not allowed, there is a dining table where you can bring your own food and a spacious living room where the whole family can sit together, which is a huge plus for families traveling together.   The new meat added here and there makes it feel even more special. Since it was a room on the upper floor with a great view, the view from the balcony was really refreshing. Most rooms at the Belvedere, including the Premier Suites, have outside balconies, allowing you to enjoy the cool sea breeze. There are two bedrooms in total.   The main bedroom with king-size bed is located inside.  The bright wood feel and bedding colors give it a resort-like feel.  The main bedroom is also connected to the bathroom.   I especially like that there is a bathtub with a view so you can bathe while looking out the window. Aveda products are also provided in the Premier Suite.  The second bedroom is connected to the living room and has two twin beds. As this is a room for 4 people in the garden, there is a separate bathroom at the entrance so you can use it without any hassle. In fact, the Premier Suite room is a room that can only be reserved by those with a separate membership, so it has been difficult for the general public to use it . This year, some Premier Suite rooms are said to be available for general reservations as well.   You ca n't miss it while it's good, right?  Standard rooms are divided into Royal, Suite, and Deluxe .  Let me show you the best royal room first .   The Royal Room is even larger than the Premier Suite in terms of room size .  In fact, hotels can sometimes feel a bit stuffy when traveling with family, but resorts like Beaverdeer have the advantage of being able to relax comfortably without feeling stuffy at all.  There are two bedrooms, one inside the living room and one to the right of the entrance. Both rooms are well-lit and neatly decorated.  There are also two bathrooms, and the main bathroom has a bathtub. However, the view from the bathtub is not an ocean view.  The rooms also have spacious balconies surrounding them.  The suite rooms, one level below, are smaller than the royal rooms .  There is a living room and kitchen of a reasonable size, so there is more than enough space for a family to comfortably use.  Best of all, in the Sweet Ocean View Room, you can choose to view Geoga Bridge in addition to Mongdol Beach . It's a special view that can only be seen from Devon.  It's not just the Geoga Bridge that you can see, but the mountains and the sea behind the resort are also visible.   If the view from the front of the resort, Mondore Beach, was exciting and had a summery feel, the view from Gwaga Bridge was a quiet, static view with only the sound of the wind blowing, so I personally really liked the view from Geoga Bridge . There are two bedrooms, one with a bed and one with an ondol-style floor heating, so it would be good for traveling with children or parents who would prefer an ondol-style floor heating than a bed .  There are two bathrooms, but no bathtub .  Lastly, the deluxe room located in the West Wing.  This is a basic room available at the most reasonable price .  Nonetheless, all rooms have ocean views.   It looks similar to a typical hotel room.  You'll notice that there are tables and chairs to sit facing each other for a moment .  It's also fun that there's a small desk and sink behind the bed . The sink is outside and the toilet and shower are separate. Overall, I felt that the rooms at Belvedere were spacious, clean, and practically decorated like a resort, making them a great choice for families . For family travelers, the rooms are important, but how well the water play facilities are equipped is also important.  Everdean features an indoor and outdoor pool on the 2nd floor, and an infinity pool on the 20th floor .  Above all, both pools are parallel to the sea, so when you swim, you feel like you are in the sea.  In particular, the infinity pool on the 20th floor is a unique charm that only Geojedo Island has.  It is the perfect place to enjoy the breathtaking view of the blue sea and the islands of Gungungun . Since it operates on a reservation system and is only available to adults, it is perfect for those who want to swim quietly.  Also, one end of the pool is transparent, so it feels like you're swimming in the sky, but it's also a little scary.  I highly recommend it to anyone who is ambitious about life. If you want to use it at a reasonable price, there are packages that include use of Infinity Park, so it would be a good idea to compare prices carefully.  The indoor/outdoor pool on the second floor is primarily for children.  Since it is located parallel to the sea, you can still get the feeling of an infinity pool even though the height is low .  It's quite large and has attractions that kids would enjoy, so I thought I'd like to come here with my nephew.  The transparent floor I saw at the infinity pool on the 20th floor is also here.   It was impressive to see the children raising their hands excitedly.  The indoor swimming pool is also decorated in a unified style, so it does n't feel stuffy, and it's quite large, so it's great for kids to play in the water and feel the ocean vibe even when the weather is bad or in the winter .  In addition, the resort offers a wide variety of activities for children to enjoy .  Everdeer's Bounce Trampoline Park is a popular attraction among children, featuring trampolines and gym lines for them to enjoy .  In addition, there is the Pororo Kids Cafe, the Drawing Cafe where you can draw with your child, and Bring Live where you can play with My Pop-Up Lego blocks .  You may be wondering what I did for fun when I didn't have a child .  The landscaping in front of the resort is very well maintained, making it a great place for a walk. Ongdu Beach is also the resort's private beach, so it was quiet and nice to walk around.   You can also enjoy yacht sailing and on-board fishing at the marina, taking in the beauty of the Geoje sea. If you take a sunset cruise, you can enjoy a cool sea breeze and tour every nook and cranny of the resort and the Geoga Bridge for 1 hour and 10 minutes. Above all, the night view of the resort when you return to the pier is truly beautiful. Even if you don't go yachting, I highly recommend going to Marina Tras at one hour to see the night view .  In addition, there is a Bell Spa on the 3rd floor of the East Building.   The spa is much larger and better decorated than I thought .  There is also a family room where you can receive spa treatment together with your family, so you can create fun memories by receiving spa treatment together with your family .  Breakfast is served in two locations as the resort is large.  I used it on the 20th floor, Elfloor. Elfloor has a great view and is a nice space.  The buffet menu was pretty good considering the price.  In addition, there are various types of gold mining in the city.   I was very impressed by the Chidder Trass, which is located closest to the sea in the West Wing.  This means that you can taste a variety of fish, and you can taste premium seafood using Geoje Island's local ingredients .  Among them, the lunch omakase was truly special.  You can enjoy a shack view while looking out at the sea in a separate private space inside the establishment .  The food served was also made with seasonal ingredients unique to Geoje Island, and the taste was excellent. However, the atmosphere was also great as I ate while taking in the view of the sea and listening to the sound of the waves.  I highly recommend going when the weather is nice, you wo n't regret it .  In addition, there are various restaurants in Busan and Gyeongnam, such as Gourmet and Cafe Black Up Coffee, so you can comfortably take care of your meals within the resort.  We stayed at Geoje Belvedere for 2 days and 1 night and filmed without any rest, so it was really hard.  Once you go there, you get the feeling that it is a well-decorated family resort with plenty of things to enjoy.  But despite that, there are people who think that Haeundae is the best in the south.  So far, I've reviewed all the Oseong hotels in Haeundae, but I've never introduced a resort for families. Let's take a look at Hanwha Resort Haeundae, a place where you can enjoy family time at a reasonable price while enjoying a view comparable to that of a luxurious five-star hotel. Hanwha-ri Jotound is one of the best places to view Gwanghan Bridge, Busan's representative landmark .  I actually toured both the low-rise and high-rise ocean view rooms, and of course, the view of Gwanghan Bridge from the high-rise rooms was amazing.  Surprisingly, the view from the lower floors was great, as Gwanghan Bridge felt very close. Furthermore, because it's a resort, the basic room size starts at 4 people.  Usually, hotels charge extra for each additional person, or even if you pay, the maximum is three people, so resorts definitely have a big advantage for families .  Hana Resort Haeundae has three main room types: Family, Deluxe, and Royal.  First, let's take a look at the Royal Room, which is a good choice for large families traveling together.   The living room is huge and has large windows that offer a view of the beautiful Busan ocean.  There is a dining table and kitchen that can accommodate six people. Cooking is also possible, and simple cooking utensils and dishes are provided so you can prepare your own meals . There are two rooms in total.  The master bedroom is spacious with a bed and an ocean view .  Another room is an ondol room, so you can use it by laying down a prepared friend .  The bathroom is also clean.  If you are traveling with a smaller number of people, you may also want to consider a deluxe room .  It consists of one living room and one room .  Although smaller than the Royal Room, it has a living room and kitchen of a reasonable size .  The rooms at Hanwha Resort Haound are not overly fancy, but they are practical and neatly decorated. The advantage was that it had a great view that rivaled that of the nearby luxury hotels.   The resort's amenities include a sauna, where you can bathe while enjoying a 56-degree view that is as spectacular as the view of Gwanghan Bridge .  There is a convenience store and karaoke room in the basement .  Haeundae Hana Resort is close to both Haeundae and Gwanghalli, making it a great choice for exploring both beaches. Another great feature is the promenade that runs along the beach right in front of the resort . I also went jogging to Haeundae in the morning, and maybe because I'm a country bumpkin from Seoul, I really enjoyed running while receiving the treatment.   There are many delicious restaurants around the resort, making it a great place to explore the city and try different restaurants. Furthermore, the resort has partnerships with various tourist destinations in Busan, so if you make a reservation through the resort, you can enjoy various facilities at discounted prices. Representative examples include Haeundae Blue Line Park, which is currently the hottest tourist attraction in Busan, Sunshine Ailing Knot, and X-the-Sky, the second-highest observatory in Korea, which you can use at discounted prices.   The food is served at the PCN Silside Kitchen located on the second floor .  Are the schematic prices real?  Even if the entire family uses it, it can be used at a reasonable price of less than 100,000 won.  That does n't mean the facilities or food quality are low.  The view is great and the food is clean, so you can eat your fill without feeling burdened .  But the restaurant I would personally recommend the most is Cloud 32, located at the highest point of the 32-story resort.   It is a luxurious and stylish place that is comparable to the Osung Hotel, with a cool and open view.  Actually, I thought that the restaurant with a view of the Gwanghan Bridge from a high-rise building was only available at a nearby hotel .  But that wasn't the case.  Plus, the price range is much more reasonable. Even though it was a dinner course paired with two glasses of wine, Cloud 32's signature course menu, the 56 Guy Course, was available for 120,000 won per person .  The course started with an amuse bouche and included grilled scallops, mushroom soup, live squid, risotto, lobster tail, and abalone.  For the main course, I had a choice between sirloin and tenderloin. The meat was tender and perfectly paired with a port wine sauce. Dessert and tea were also served. If you are traveling to Busan and are thinking of having a romantic dinner, I think this is the best choice in terms of atmosphere, value for money, and taste .  Also, Olivia, a cafe on the first floor famous for its atmospheric restaurant, recently reopened after renovation.   They say that on weekends, a market selling public offerings is held at the Cafe Barohapgongteo, so it might be a good idea to visit. So far, I've introduced you to two resorts in the Gyeongsang region with great ocean views. If you want to have fun with your children in a quiet fishing village rather than a crowded city, Geoje Belvedere is the place to go. If you are traveling to Busan with your family and want to enjoy both a reasonable price and a great view, I recommend Hanari Jot Haeundae .  If today's video was helpful to you on your travels, please subscribe, like, and turn on notifications.  Until now, I have been a man who leaves again and again. thank you [music]

My name is a luxury hotel chain that is famous worldwide for its paradoxical yet comfortable atmosphere. In Korea, it first opened on October 1, 2015, at the intersection of Gwanghwamun Station. It is the only hotel to be named a 5-star hotel by Cobis TV ID, along with Shilla Ute. Looking at the exterior of the building, it looks like an ordinary high-rise building in downtown Seoul, but when you go inside, you can see the unique characteristics of the calm yet luxurious Four Seasons Hotel. The hotel entrance has a mocha-like painting, and even the decoration behind the check-in counter shows the classic yet Korean aspect that the hotel aims for. The part decorated with flowers that match the opening was also impressive. Well, the Sense Hotel has 7 types of regular rooms, 2 types of suites, and 3 types of top suites. Among the suites, I chose Gyeongbokgung Palace.  The only jacket-tie suite in the Felice with a table was 20, and I was asked about it on the 8th floor. Upon entering the room, the living room is located, and the floor-to-ceiling glass windows are the first thing that catches your eye. You can see the center of South Korea, including Gyeongbokgung Palace and the Blue House, at a glance. The living room space, with its marble floor and bright green carpet, is neat and tidy rather than flashy. The design by the UK's lkey w design works was inspired by the various aspects of Hanok and created patterns throughout the room. I liked how the unique carpet shape, the grid pattern on the mirror, the paintings on the wall, and the cushion sofa all unified the Korean look. There is an LG LCD TV, and welcome chocolates and cards are provided for the living room table, as well as a quarantine kit. There is a separate office space near the entrance and a place to hang your coat. Following the hallway is the atrium. The bedroom is much larger than the living room, but because it is a suite located in a black corner, it is cool and open with floor-to-ceiling glass on both sides. When you open your eyes from the bed,  Gyeongbokgung Palace is right in front of you. The view from the hotel room is very different. It feels like lying in the center of the world. Since the glass is on both sides, you have to be careful of the pie light, and you have to be careful that you can be insured against eye damage if you don't close the curtains in the morning. These days, regulars at 5-star hotels have a Simos bed, and my friend's bed is from the American hotel bedding company So*Vextex. The Korean style was also evident on the wall behind the bed and on the dresser. The vanity mirror hanging on a leather strap was particularly unique. Personally, I prefer rooms with large windows and good lighting. The spaciousness and urban feel were just my style. Between the bedroom and living room is the bathroom and bathtub, which are the highlights of the room. I personally feel stuffy when I'm in hot water, but the view is refreshing. Oh, and the salt that was prepared and the bathtub that I just dazed myself in were healing. The bathtub that was meticulously prepared, with a headrest and a TV, is something even those who don't like their alma mater can't help but soak in.  It is a built-in TV in the bathroom with stylish lighting and marble, so you can watch a drama without any interruption in the story while brushing your teeth. Amenities 4 are products from Natural PC, a Spanish skincare brand. Sam & There is a shower room and toilet separated by a separate partition at the back. Various amenities including toothpaste and slippers are provided. There is a minibar and a space for drinking tea in the hallway at the end of the bathroom. The tea set was very pretty. You can drink the Kim Dong-kwon Ssanggyemyeongcha provided. Lee City 100 from an American organic handmade tea company and espresso coffee capsules are also provided. It is included in the use of the Club Lounge located on the 8th floor of the Pens PU Executive Suite N10. If you go for afternoon tea time, you can have dessert and tea. When I visited, instead of a traditional meal, it was served individually. It was not served on a three-tiered tray like other hotels, but a plate full of delicious desserts was provided. The south and west views that I could not see from the room can be seen in the lounge.  There was a happy hour with unlimited drinks and food, and I hope you'll believe it and live your life in one of the few places in Seoul that serves champagne. I had breakfast as room service for quarantine reasons. I had Japanese, Western, and Korean food, and they were all delicious without any shortcomings. Rather than moving around diligently from the morning and eating buffet-style, it was better to have a full meal in the room like this. The rooms and lounge are great, but the Four Seasons Hotel is actually more famous for its gym, Spa 4 Canal. It was especially famous for requiring a 100 million won deposit to sign up for a gym membership. The 765-square-meter fitness club was, as expected, the most utilized of all the domestic hotel gyms I've been to. Not only was the space large and the view out the window, but there was also a variety of equipment, including socks, workout clothes, swimwear, and disposable head covers. There was nothing to complain about. The pool felt a bit small, but I wasn't able to take a picture, but the inside of the changing room was amazing. So, what would your overall review be if you were to guess at the Four Seasons Seoul? First of all, it's definitely my favorite hotel. Personally, I don't like the hustle and bustle of the city, but the hotel itself was relatively calm, which was nice. The gym was so memorable that I really want to go there again. The staff and service are definitely top-notch in Korea. Above all, when I was promoted to the second stage of social fish and had difficulty using the swimming pool and gym, unlike other hotels, I was impressed that they gave me a pass that I could use after the next stage. We’re moving out of our terrible Airbnb and into a 5-star hotel in Seoul. The Airbnb location was central and the space was big; however, the reason I call it terrible is because of the horrible sewer smell. It gets worse whenever we use the shower or sink, so I had to remove all my skincare and toothbrush from the bathroom and use the kitchen sink instead. If I had to describe the smell, I’d say it smelled like vomit. We’re both surprised that none of the reviews mentioned this. The host admitted she was fully aware of the smell and told us to directly file a complaint with the building’s management office… which is ridiculous and unacceptable! We’re definitely leaving an honest review so others will know before booking. Jason decided to order a Kakao Taxi because we had so much luggage, and Kakao offers a van option, while Uber in Korea doesn't provide that. We’re heading to the Shilla Hotel in Seoul for 6 days and 5 nights, paying $600 a night. If you want to spot celebrities, this is one of the hotels they often stay at. With its perfect blend of traditional, heritage-inspired style—reflecting its dynastic roots —and contemporary design, the Shilla Seoul truly balances past, present, and future. The moment we got out of our taxi, we were immediately greeted by professionals in suits who helped us every step of the way. One thing I noticed is that their service really is top-notch. Shilla provided some of the best hospitality we’ve ever experienced at a high-end hotel. The lobby looked mesmerizing with its famous hanging crystals. Since we arrived earlier than our check-in time, we just dropped off our bags and went out for lunch. We decided to check out the Shilla Duty Free mall, but I was quickly stopped and told not to film. In Korea, taking photos or videos are quite sensitive matter. Even in public, you need consent; that’s why most Korean influencers blur people’s faces so they won’t get sued. I find it a bit ridiculous, considering there are CCTV cameras and vehicles with black boxes recording everywhere in Korea. But then again, Korea has huge issues with “Molka,” which means hidden camera. People sometimes film others without consent in public places for bad reasons. For instance, spy cameras have created fear among women about being filmed without knowing. This made filming tricky, but I tried my best to avoid any problems. We didn’t see anything good to eat in the Duty Free mall, so we went outside the Shilla Hotel. Jason found this hidden “gem” restaurant we really enjoyed; the menu was simple, prices were reasonable, and the portions were huge. Hey guys, so I just want to say that the Shilla Hotel is actually on a hill. So they do offer a bunch of like shuttle bus services like from a bunch of locations. So you don't have to go up those big hills. And they're quite convenient and comfortable. They offer free buses to popular areas like Myeongdong too. Once we got back to our hotel, they gave us the keys and mentioned our bags were already in the room. The room was honestly pretty spacious to me. Plus, we had the best view of Namsan Tower every morning. I think this hotel has, like the best view of Namsan Tower. We didn’t want to head out again, and since our wedding is tomorrow, so we decided to order room service instead. Jason got the samgyetang (a traditional Korean chicken soup) for ₩65,000, and I ordered a phat Thai for ₩42,000. And then our wedding happened! If you’d like to see our wedding day vlog, the link will be in the description below! Good morning. Looks like we overslept. It's like already 11:30am. But, today I really want to take some time to really check out the hotel. I’ll go to the gym and try their food. So come join me today. To start off the day, we had lunch at the Library Lounge on the first floor. So we’re at the library. Koreans are quite particular about what you film. So I don't want to film other people’s faces right now. I’ll film the food. While we were waiting for our food, we got a ridiculous request from our Airbnb host, asking us to rate them 5 stars in exchange for a Starbucks gift card. How can they try to bribe us for a fake review? Tsk tsk tsk. Don’t worry—we wrote a very honest review despite So this is our Airbnb, umm so it says , like, you know a five star review event so that you get a Starbucks gift card. As long as you put a five star, but if it's a  five star review only. Because I was so confused, right? Because like, we had that smell issue and I scanned through all of the reviews. I would not give them a five star. I scanned through all of their reviews and not a single place mention this smell. So I was like, oh, is a new thing? But then I found out that it's like it's always been there. So I'm surprised..but that's why, because they are giving... they are doing this 5 star review thing where like... And then, the same thing for my mom’s Airbnb where like if you give a positive review, you get a Starbucks gift card. So I guess that's what they're doing at Airbnb now. That's why there are so many places with five star reviews But they don't deserve the five star. Yeah yeah because they are doing this, we are going to give you this gift card. I guess it works for them, right? It makes sense. They just give a five stars. But that's bribing people! It's like a $5 gift card, I am assuming...but I ordered their chargrilled Korean beef cheeseburger for a whopping ₩52,000, while Jason got the Croque Monsieur for ₩43,000. The fries were crispy and tasty, kind of like McDonald’s fries. The portions were perfect, but honestly, at these prices, I should’ve just gone somewhere cheaper. The food tasted average, nothing particularly special. But the real reason we came here was to try Shilla's famous and super expensive bingsoo, Korean shaved ice cream. It’s been on my Korea bucket list for awhile. The one I wanted to try was mango, but it’s seasonal, so the one they had during our visit was the Honeycomb Bingsu, called “Bingsky.” They include cacao nibs cookies and Jirisan Mountain’s wild honey, which is collected only once a year after the first frost of winter. It’s said to be one of the best honeys in Korea because it’s rich in propolis, pollen, and wax from wild bees that feed on hundreds of flowers in Jirisan Mountain’s pollution-free areas at altitudes higher than 600 meters from spring to fall. It costs ₩68,000 or ₩118,000 with whiskey. It was HUGE, and we immediately regretted eating lunch first. Honestly, it’s best shared with four people, especially since the sides have free refills. We didn’t ask for more because it was already too much for the two of us. The honey was insanely sweet and rich. The honeycomb itself didn’t have that waxy flavour most honeycombs have. In one phrase: it was as pure as honey can get. There were so many flavours and combinations you could make with all the sides, so we never got sick of just one taste. This is the big honeycomb that I am going to eat. Oh, It’s pure honey. I don't even taste the wax. It's just like pure honey. It just melts in your mouth. But...it genuinely taste different than the honey I’ve gotten in Canada. I can actually tell the difference. No. For sure, I’ve never tasted this kind of honey before. I guess this is what real honey taste like? So cold. I'm so glad you brought the jacket down because I’m freezing. Now that we're eating this, I'm, like, so much colder. I can make you tea upstairs. You don’t want tea? It’s a lot of liquid already Yeah, but it’s good for your throat no? I guess. Remember we are eating again in 3 hours. It’s not not even three hours, it’s 3 o’clock (Dinner at 5PM) We're leaving in, like, two hours for dinner. We really tried to finish as much as possible, but we still ended up leaving about half. At least, we finished all the honey, which is where the real value is. Was it worth it? Definitely worth trying once, because you can pay a lot for honey alone, but it’s not easy to get fresh honeycomb from that area. After eating, we checked out Shilla’s amenities and the gym. Okay, we're going to go to the gym now. The entire place is beautifully decorated with crystal accents. They were pretty strict about filming, so I couldn’t record much. They have a Korean sauna, spa, beauty salon, a huge gym with physicians on standby, plus a walking path, pilates studio, golf range, indoor pool, and a rooftop pool /cabana. During our stay, we saw like polices and bodyguards all over our hotel. I think some famous people like politicians and maybe even the president of Korea are here attending the weddings. I didn’t want to get in trouble, so I didn’t film anything. There’s another wedding today? There’s a lot of weddings happening. Did you say it’s fully booked? Every weekend is fully booked until 2025, I believe. Wow. Yeah, it’s a $127,000 just to rent. Walking around to digest what we ate. Not long after, it was dinner time! Around 4:50 PM, the first floor got packed with a line out the door for the famous Parkview Buffet at Shilla. It’s known as one of the most luxurious buffets in Seoul, priced at a steep ₩192,000 per person for dinner. We were seated and given a free bottle of San Pellegrino along with a choice of one glass of wine per person. It seems I lost some of my video footage, but the buffet included nine sections like fresh seafood like snow crabs, and sushi. Western cuisine like pasta, pizza, and seafood. Asian cuisine, specifically Chinese wok items. Vietnamese pho noodles Grilled meat and seafood Chinese dim sum and fried foods Korean side dishes Fresh veggies and salads And of course, dessert Because of the time limit, everyone rushed in to grab food, and it was actually a bit of a shit show. We started with fresh seafoods, then the grilled meats and seafoods. While we were eating, they brought a mushroom cream pie soup to each person. I didn’t eat it, but Jason tried some. He said it was super heavy, basically pure cream, and the pastry on top was really buttery. It's probably a trap to fill you up since you know you're paying a lot of money. But Jason said it tasted good, just not worth the stomach real estate. We sampled a bit of everything, but the roasted tenderloin and rack of lamb with mint sauce were the best bang for your buck and Jason’s favourites. Once we were nearly full, we moved on to the last section: desserts, which had pastries, chocolate, cheese, fruit, and jello. Overall, the food was delicious but not worth the amount we paid for. I’ll post a video in the future about another buffet we went to in Korea that we thought was really worth it. Let’s just say it involved unlimited caviar! Subscribe so you don’t miss that video when I post it. Mont-blanc Towards the end, right before we had to leave, they handed us the bill. Since we were staying at the Shilla Hotel, we got a free $100 discount on the buffet! Our total bill ended up at 285,000 won. After we finished eating, we opened our wedding gifts, checking each envelope one by one. In asian culture, we recorded everything in a book. so we can keep track who gave how much. So we found a fancy envelope out of all of these envelopes that we've opened up. Among them, one of them was the fanciest and the most touching one was another that really stood out.
