[Music] Welcome to the Lotte City  Hotel. We stayed four nights here. Come along for a tour of the room. When you walk  in on your left is where you pop in your card so you can power up the room. And on your right is a  closet, where there's two robes and some hangers. There's a safe where you can store your items  and a laundry bag in case you need to do laundry. And a set of slippers to lounge in. There's  luggage racks so you can put your luggage on it. When you walk over there's a cabinet  where underneath is a refrigerator where they provide you with two bottles  of complimentary water every day. And there's a kettle to heat up hot water so  you can make coffee, noodles, tea. They also provide you with complimentary tea and coffee  and two cups. And then you have a nice sized TV, which has a few Western options. A little  workspace area where you have some outlets where you can charge your items. A great little  sitting area where you can look out and get a really nice view of the city. Oh my god, look how  high up we are. We're actually on the 25th floor. And the bed, it's large and it's comfortable  and it also has an outlet on the one side. This bathroom is really nice. You have a giant  shower with a rainfall shower head and a wand. Then there's conditioner, shower  gel, shampoo and you have a sponge. And the sink is really nice as well. There is  lotion, soap, they give you two cups. And of course, there's this amazing Asian toilet, which  I really have to get one of these for my house. This hotel has a really nice fitness center  where they have a lot of cardio equipment and they also have free weights. They even  have free towels and water. The hotel has a laundry room that has two washing machines, two dryers. You can purchase laundry  detergent out of the vending machine and there also is two ironing boards, two  irons. Andaz is a brand that I really enjoy,  but this property in Seoul simply doesn’t live up to the brands upscale reputation. Hi there, my name is Kevin. This channel came from a love of traveling, a love of the full  process and the journey itself. I feature airline trip reports and high end hotel reviews from all  over the world. My reviews aren’t sponsored by airlines or hotels so you can be sure to get  my unbiased honest opinion. Am I an expert? You can decide. Am I fair? Yea, I am. Let’s get into it, welcome to Seoul. If you’d like to know the exact  nightly rate that I paid for my stay or my next five videos in queue,  please check out the description below. The Andaz Gangnam has two entrances. In the  front for pedestrians and in the rear there is a driveway for car pickup and drop offs. Note  that despite the hotel doing quite a good job with their photography angles, the hotel does have  an elevated roadway directly in front of it. When checking in, you’ll have a seat at one of  the front desks, which are awkwardly too low and you’ll be offered a cup of tea. Service at check  in and throughout most, but not all of the hotel is in a characteristic American Hyatt familiar  conversational manner, at least in English. Andaz, in Hindi, means personal style and so,  each property is designed to blend the style of it’s specific location with that of the target  customer. It’s not to my personal taste but, I do think it accomplishes this pretty well in the  colors, textures and shapes used throughout the property, but… I’m not a fan of the ground  floor and connecting first floor layout. For a hotel with 241 rooms, the lobby footprint  is on the smaller side as it is, but then when you put this giant centerpiece of a staircase smack in  the middle of it- it just begs the question, why? The hotel is located in central Seoul in it’s name  sake Gangnam district, in the northern part of it. By taxi, you can expect a drive to either  Gimpo or Incheon to take a solid hour or more, but the hotel is located just next to the  Apgujeong Metro station and is on a street that is literally lined with cosmetic surgery clinics. In the rear of the lobby is A-Z Cafe and Gallery offering a variety of pastries  and drinks throughout the day. On the other side of the stair case we have  the elevators which will take us to the guest room floors. I booked a balcony King room and  in retrospect, I’d not book the balcony unless you really need it, simply because the balcony  rooms are all in the annex building of sorts which means you’ll be guaranteed a low floor room. On the left is the primary hotel tower and the three levels of balcony rooms  are in this shorter structure. The corridors like most of the property are  stark and modern but through a mixed palette of neutral tones and well placed lighting,  it never feels particularly barren or cold. Throughout the hotel and especially inside the rooms the asymmetric angles are meant to  reference the patchwork quality of bojagi. Bojagi are the traditional Korean  wrapping cloths used in significant ceremonies as gift wrap to preserve good luck,  according to traditional Korean folklore. Inside the room, the room itself has angled  walls and an oddly shaped bathroom which I think puts form over function. Overall the room is comfortable and nicely equipped for the size, but  considering this hotel just opened in 2019, it’s clear that using quality materials  was not the MO of the designers here. The room has a smart tablet next to the bedside  which is meant to perform all of the in room functions, but in English at least, it’s certainly  not the most efficient way to get things done. The mini bar area is nicely  laid out and compartmentalized. I always think it’s nice when you can  sort of put the mini bar facilities away. As is a brand standard for Andaz, mini bar snacks  and drinks are free, but when I checked in, there was no mention of this at all. I’ve  read recently that Andaz is “reimagining” their minibars so in the mean time, I would  always ask for clarity before consuming. I appreciate that there are well  labeled controls and plenty of outlets, though no USB C, on both sides of the  bed, but the raised placement is a bit strange- not complaining though, just different. Upon check in there was quite a large piece of  pineapple cake on the central table, though that cloche has certainly seen better days. Then we have the bathroom which is split. In this small area separated by a  sliding door we have a single vanity with plenty of shelving and a decent sized walk in shower. The  toilet area we will see is near the front door. Bathroom amenities included  soaps by Christophe Laudamiel. I did get the feeling this room was meant for a  different guest though as there were children’s toiletries also setup in the bathroom and a  third pair of childrens slippers in the closet. Finally, we have the toilet room with a 2nd sink. The entry closet and toilet  area can also be closed off from the rest of the room by double sliding doors. Finally to the balcony, which was nice to  get some fresh air, but ultimately I think unnecessary. Just a few cleanliness and condition issues in the room. The glass was just filthy, looks like  they attempted to clean it with a dirty towel. Then are are a lot of tiny minor nicks and  scratches which on their own aren’t significant, but when a room has this many dents and  scuffs after just four years of use, I don’t want to think about how  it’ll look five years from now. The worst offender was the floor in the bathroom  which was clearly not meant to get wet, but it completely rotted through and warped. Last up, just lots of dust in quite a few areas above eye level. The cleanliness problems weren’t deal breakers, but the condition especially  of that floor was really poor showing. Before we head to the hall of  restaurants for dinner, let’s just quickly look at who is going to be staying here. Couples in their 20s-40s is the dominant group you’ll find here with a few young families  and perhaps some medical tourists as well. The hotel has its moments of being understated and relaxed but as I’ll talk about later,  also has a slightly pretentious side. Ok, so dinner. If you ever find yourself on  their website trying to figure out what the dining concept is, good luck. Let me tell you what  they say it is, “Ascending the central staircase, guests arrive at JOGAKBO, which means  ‘traditional patchwork’ in Korean, offers a sophisticated reinterpretation of  Seoul’s immersive street and alleyway dining. Three drinking and dining venues  flow seamlessly into adjacent spaces, allowing guest to conveniently explore a  variety of creative, locally inspired cuisine. That is the biggest crock of  s*** if ever I’ve heard one. Let me translate it. It’s one big open  space. Three restaurants in a railway design, walking through one to get to the next. They  mention it’s supposed to be reminiscent of Seoul’s immersive street dining  and locally inspired cuisine. One restaurant is all day dining,  surrounding the staircase, then is the Seafood restaurant and behind  that the steak house. All three restaurants, not a single Korean item on any of the menus.  Some great locally inspired cuisine that is. I saw before I left my room that the room  service menu had a few basic Korean dishes on it and I asked if I would be able to  order from that menu in the restaurant and they graciously accommodated me. There weren’t many choices, I went with a bibimbap and it was very good, but my God, never  has a dining concept ever been such a let down. Anyway, day began to turn to night and I caught  the tail end of the sunset from my balcony. Waking up early the next morning, I identified  with this… duck? And I headed down to The Summer House which is the name of their  wellness facility on the basement level. Down here is an indoor pool and a fitness  center which I wanted to get some quick clips of and ohhh they did not like  that- especially in the pool area. Mind you, we all have eyes, we can  see there was absolutely no one here. Anyway, the LED screen gives it a really strange  dystopian vibe, but hey, some might like it. The fitness center was very well equipped though  and pretty beautiful as far as fitness centers go. Finally our last stop is back to the  canteen, I mean Jogakbo for breakfast, where they do serve up a nice buffet. When creating a hotel or flight review, what do you think are some of the most  important characteristics about those reviews? To me, to make a truly unbiased review, two  things need to be true. First, I need to pay a fare or rate that is publicly available and  receive no special treatment or compensation. Second, I need to film anonymously. So rest  assured that this video today is exactly what I say it is, an unbiased review. And  that is why your likes, comments and subscriptions mean so much, they really do help  the channel to grow and continue to put out this twice weekly and soon three times weekly  content. My patreon is also linked below. These have to be the most perfect  eggs I’ve ever seen. All of it. And finally I found where they’re  hiding all of the Korean food. Though the chopsticks sticking out of  each dish is giving me a bit of angst. Ok, so, overall three things went wrong  here. A totally disjointed food concept, a strange use of the public spaces and  lots of cheap materials in the room. That said, it’s not a bad hotel, but it’s  certainly not a place I’d be returning to. Despite that, I do hope you enjoyed the video.  If you did, please be sure to click that thumbs up button and subscribe with notifications on  so you don’t miss the rest of this 12 country, 21 hotel, 15 flight mega trip. I’ll see you  next time on T’way Air from Seoul to one of my absolute favorite places on earth, Tokyo.  Oh, and thanks for watching until the end.

You walk into The Terrace, an airy, restaurant-sized space right across from the lobby. Imagine seven live buffet stations, each offering something freshly made to order—eggs, breads, even mini pancakes and waffles The first thing guests point out? The view. Opt for a window seat early in the morning, especially before 8 a.m.—it’s quieter, more peaceful, and you’re gifted a front-row panorama of Seoul that turns eating into a vibe Many visitors say they’d happily come just for that calm, early-morning atmosphere. As for the food, reviews are fair but positive. You get the essentials: freshly baked breads, pastries, charcuterie boards, a cereal and fresh juice section A standout feature is the made-to-order egg station—the omelets are fluffy, personalized, and paired with attentive, friendly chefs On the Korean side, the offerings are more modest than at some other luxury hotels—so there’s a noodle station, rice porridge, and a few traditional dishes—but it’s not the star focus. This hotel is pretty, but it feels strangely a bit excessive. It is said to be decorated with the motif of the Verepoque period in 19th century Paris, France, but the concept is so extreme that opinions are extremely divided. Let's find out together how Another Leaving Man felt. [Music] Hello, I am Another Leaving Man. The 4-star boutique hotel SKE that I will introduce today is located at Exit 7 of Hoewon Station, which has a strange atmosphere where the traditional market Namdaemun Market and the high-end department store Shinsegae Department Store coexist. SK2 is the first brand that was independently launched in 2018 by Shinsegae Chosun Hotel without the help of a foreign hotel chain. It is said that Vice Chairman Chung Yong-jin of Shinsegae Group shared it in particular. The hotel was built with the concept of the Verepoque period of the 19th century, one of the most splendid periods in France, as a boutique hotel with 204 rooms. Even the design was designed by Jacques Garcia, who received the Légendonné, and the name of the hotel was built with the meaning of escape in mind. However,  The hotel's first impression is that it 's located in an oddly-shaped office building, making you wonder if it's a hotel. You can barely tell it's a hotel by the entrance. However, from the first-floor entrance, you can feel the authenticity of a French boutique hotel. The black-and-white checkered floor, wine-colored furniture, and even the mirrored wall in front, decorated like a real pink muhly, give it the feel of a well-decorated cafe. The elevators, which appear around the corner, have similar yet different patterns, black-and-white floors, dreamy lighting, and even vintage mirrors, continuing the hotel's unique concept. There's a desk, but actual check-in is done at the 7th-floor front desk. Even the elevator to the 7th floor has a very French feel, with announcements coming in both Korean and English. The 7th-floor hallway is adorned with bright pink flower arrangements. To the left and right of the front desk are check-in desks. Initially, only the space on the right was used as the front desk, while the space on the left was occupied by a cafe called Hell Cafe. However, perhaps because the front desk was too small for the size of the guest rooms, both spaces are now occupied.  It's being used as a front desk. I had a strong impression of the first-floor entrance, but the front desk on the 7th floor felt even more impressive. The red walls look even more intense through the contrast of the large floral carpet and the black wainscoting. The furniture and various paintings that don't look ordinary at all are amazing. It's surprising that there is such a unique place in Seoul that feels like you've simultaneously traveled through time and space. L' Escape Hotel has four types of regular rooms and five types of suites. The rooms I'm going to show you today are the Atelier Suite, the most basic of the suites, and the Secret Room, a mid-level regular room. Before I get into the details of the rooms, I'd like to share a tip that travelers should definitely know. These days, we use smartphones and the internet almost all the time, not only when traveling but also in everyday life. In particular, I worried a lot about my financial information or personal information being exposed when I used a credit card or logged into social media that contained personal information for online banking while traveling. That's why I started using a VPN. When using public Wi-Fi, such as at an airport or hotel, anyone connected to the same Wi-Fi only needs basic computer knowledge.  They say that even with a VPN, you can steal personal information like credit card information or passwords. That's why the VPN I trust and use is Express VPN, which I'm introducing today. It's an app that 100% encrypts your network data and uses the highest-level encryption, making it unbreakable even by hackers with supercomputers. It's incredibly simple to use, with just one button press. You can also change your online location, allowing you to watch thousands of movies and dramas on Netflix, which offers different content by country. For example, if you connect to Turkey, you can watch Harry Potter, or if you connect to India, you can watch Blade Season 2. You can also watch domestic sports matches on JTBC or SPOTV, which are not available overseas while traveling. If you sign up using the special link "Tteotnam" in the "More Videos" section and the pinned comment, you'll also receive a three-month free benefit. Go right now and protect your personal information. Now, let's go back to SK Port and take a look at the taxis. The first room you'll see is the basic suite or the Atelier Suite. The interior of the room is truly red. Red fills the eyes from every direction. It 's a sweet room, but the space is n't separated. The sofa and bedroom are open like a studio. The intense red color.  The velvet furniture and floor were gorgeous, but what really made the room extra dazzling was the silk-embroidered wallpaper. I initially wondered if it was a fake, but up close, it was quite elaborate and detailed. In front, there's an antique-style sofa and table, comfortably seating five people, making it perfect for a party with friends. Western paintings lining the walls reinforce the French Versailles feel, and the unified design of the lamps and lighting complements the ambiance. The bed, too, has an impressive, ornate ruffled headboard, reminiscent of a French palace. It's strikingly similar to the bed I saw in a suite at the Four Seasons Hotel in Prague, Czech Republic, not long ago. My friend's room is unusual, with a geometric design, and the matrix is ​​an Ace Hertz premium product. Beside the bed is a small round table and chair. On the nightstand is a Giga Genie, along with a room controller for controlling the lights and curtains. Even the button design matches the tone of the room. Two TVs are installed so that viewers can watch TV from both the bed and the sofa, and a work table is placed in the middle. The bathroom, located next to the bed, continues the black-and-white flooring I saw in the lobby. If only the bedroom had been a single shade of red, it would have been even more impressive.  The bathroom has impressive yellow walls and lighting. Wayne coasting decoration extends from the guest room to the bathroom, creating a unique atmosphere. The gold-tone faucet and stand lamp go well together, and even the bathroom, with its white sink and bathtub, is no joke for its Instagram-worthy vibe. However, what is the purpose of the chair next to the bathtub? I thought it was a bit inappropriate to have velvet furniture in front of the splashing bathtub, but it looks good in terms of design. The amenities are from a Spanish cosmetic brand, and the products are packaged in reusable containers. The toothpaste is uniquely provided in tablet form, so you have to chew it to create foam. I thought there would be a Dyson hairdryer because it's a suite, but it's not a Bison, it's a Deinova. The minibar next to the sofa contains a Nespresso coffee machine and Virtua capsules. Looking around up to this point, I thought it wasn't as bad as I thought, but somehow the room felt a bit stuffy. The reason was that the view from the room window was close enough to the building in front that you could see it from across the street. If you turn around, you can see Namsan Tower or Seoul Station, but the view is disappointing. But more importantly, the night view.  When you close the curtains, the red velvet makes the room really gloomy. It looks like a secret meeting is about to take place. If it were a cafe, I could just have a cup of coffee and leave, but since it's a hotel where you have to stay for one or two days, you have to endure the darkness and gloomy atmosphere for hours, and it feels a bit distracting. This shortcoming is especially noticeable in the regular rooms, which are even smaller and have less lighting. The chic guest room you're looking at now has walls decorated in red that matches the carpet instead of embroidered wallpaper. They seemed to think that red furniture would be too crazy, so they used gray and blue tones to tone it down. Unlike the Atelier Suite bathroom, which had a yellow feel, even the walls are decorated in red, and there's only one sink. It's definitely smaller than the Atelier Suite, and the lack of lighting makes the dark and gloomy shortcomings feel much more noticeable. If you ca n't find comfortable healing in your room, you should go outside. However, SKE, a boutique hotel of the highest class, doesn't have a swimming pool. The fitness center is available by reservation only, and even the fitness center is really...  It's nicely decorated. It feels more like a well-decorated fitness shop than a gym, but it's not as easy to make a reservation as you might think. Main dishes are served at the Chinese restaurant Palais de Chine on the 6th floor. Even if you're not staying at L'Escape, I've often visited here before because of the great food and atmosphere. The breakfast is a Chinese a la carte menu, with a choice of tomato soup noodles or fried rice. In addition to the return menu, bread and cereal are also available in a complimentary format. As you eat, your a la carte menu will be served. I ordered tomato soup noodles, and it was a generous meal with scrambled eggs, sausage toast, and salad. At first, I thought it was a waste to pay 33,000 won, but since I was eating a la carte at the hotel's Chinese restaurant, I thought it wasn't too bad. Suite guests can also enjoy the Savril Lounge at the Marc Davor on the 26th floor on the evening of their check-in date. Marc Davor also has a dark atmosphere that matches the overall atmosphere of the hotel, but it's okay if it's dark quickly. They offer two glasses of champagne, a cocktail, and a simple meal with scones, sausage bread, and more.  While you're there, they provide food that's good enough to have a drink. The atmosphere was great, the food was good, and everything was great, but it was a bit disappointing that you could only use it for an hour and then leave. In addition, La Mansikre, led by Chef Son Jong-won, is also located on the 26th floor, the same floor as the check-in counter. There's a Starbucks Reserve store on the 7th floor, where the check-in counter was located. If you feel like spending money on stock, you can buy coffee and a muffin to enjoy. There is a hotel in which guests can see Korea's number one treasure through the windows. This is a key luxury brand in the Marriott Group the JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square Seoul. Join me in touring all rooms the pretty swimming pool and fitness center. What's up guys! I'm DDN. Dongdaemun Shopping Complex is the mecca of wholesale fashion in Korea. It may be weird for a luxury hotel to be in this area but this is where today's hotel JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square Seoul, is. This is the second JW Marriott hotel in Seoul. The hotel is located where Dongdaemun Bus Terminal was. The terminal once gathered wholesale retail sellers from all over the country and the 11-story hotel is located there with a total of 170 rooms. As can be seen through its name the hotel faces Heunginjimun, also known as Dongdaemun which is the number one treasure of our nation. The hotel is thus special for its rare view. Shall we check in now? The hotel lobby, which is decorated with marble floors and walls is quite small for a JW Marriott hotel. The hotel itself isn't large in scale so the check-in desk and waiting area aren't big either. But the winding staircase and fancy chandelier make the simple lobby space look better. As the hotel's name has 'Dongdaemun' in it the hallways and doors are decorated in a Korean style. From the two types of basic rooms and three types of suites let's start with the most basic, Deluxe room. The first thing that caught my eye was Dongdaemun itself. As a person living in Seoul, I've been past Dongdaemun Station a lot and could see Dongdaemun here and there often but seeing it from a hotel room made it more special. Not all Deluxe rooms have a Dongdaemun view. One has to book a room with a Dongdaemun view to be able to see it. From the rooms in which Dongdaemun can be seen there are rooms with windows that only take up a part of the wall and rooms with windows as walls so to view Dongdaemun more beautifully booking the latter type would be a better idea. The room itself contained characteristics that showed JW Marriott Dongdaemun's characteristics well. Through the red carpet and furniture the room seemed more original and unlike other cliche hotel rooms. The elegant colors and Dongdaemun, visible through the window brought the Korean ambience together. The beds, which have Simmons' beauty rest mattresses also provide a roomy and comfortable sleeping space. The wall facing the bed is made of a different type of wood compared to the floor and gives the room a more traditional look. The box instead of a mini bar and a shelf with cups and wine glasses are also creative. There are also capsule coffee machines and JW Marriott Dongdaemun's own tea bags available. Towards the window, there is a very big table for work making the room great for guests on business trips and for those who want to enjoy the view from the chair. The bedroom has two entrances one from the door and one from the bed. It can be seen through a sliding door giving the room a wide, open feel. This room is not a suite but the fact that there is a small television next to the sink is also great. Behind the sink, there is a bathtub and towards the front, there is a shower booth and toilet. The shower booth has a nice sitting space and handle making it comfortable to use for those with discomfort in mobility as well. The amenities are from AROMATHERAPY Associates, an English brand and it's nice that there are hair straighteners along with hair dryers. Other than the Deluxe Room, another type of Basic room is the special Sky View Room. The room itself is similar in composition to the Deluxe Room but it is located at the top floor of the hotel and even the ceilings are windows so it feels a lot more open. From rooms near Dongdaemun to rooms towards the north side, where the Fortress Wall of Seoul is all of the 11th floor provides Sky View Rooms. Because they're on high floors and are a lot more open they are priced much higher than the other basic rooms. In terms of suites, if we exclude the unbelievable Presidential Suite there are two other types. Let's start with the Executive Suite. The Executive Suite is the room closest to Dongdaemun in the entire hotel. It basically directly faces Dongdaemun. It's in the corner, where the Fortress Wall of Seoul can be seen which brings out the ambience even more. But the living room is a bit narrow so it's not as roomy as one would expect a suite to be. On the other hand, the bedroom is just like the basic Deluxe room. I place a lot of importance on what can be seen when lying down on the bed and from the Executive Suite Dongdaemun can be seen directly. It's an amazing vibe. The bathroom is also similar to those of the basic rooms but there is a separate dressing room at the end of the hallway making it good to store luggage. Moving on to the big Deluxe Suite which is much bigger than the Executive Suite. We had booked the Executive Suite this day and were lucky enough to get an upgrade to the Deluxe Suite. I was so surprised when I saw the room. The living room was really big. It was big enough to host a party in and the back windows were as long as the walls, making the room look even bigger. But the Deluxe Suite is located in the south corner of the hotel which makes it a bit distant from Dongdaemun so if you want a room with a Dongdaemun view it'd be much better to get a Deluxe room or the Executive Suite room. Since the hotel itself doesn't have a lot of stories, and the walls are full-on glass windows knowing that one can be seen from the outside when the curtains are drawn may get on one's mind as well. The bedroom is located in the corner. Usually, the good thing about corner rooms is their view but the south corner was facing the Dongdaemun Market so that wasn't exactly a plus. But it was nice to see how there were various areas around the Suite to just sit and stare into the city. The Deluxe Suite's bathroom is very long horizontally. There is a shower space and bathtub on one end and a toilet and small sink on the other end. In the middle, there's a main sink, closet and a place to store luggage. It is a bit disappointing that there's just one sink. There is also a separate workspace towards the door. This isn't that well-known but one of the many strengths of JW Marriott Dongdaemun is its beautiful swimming pool. I can't say the pool is useful for lap swimming but the deep blue floor tiles and LED lights along with the chandeliers on top and mirrors on the side walls make guests feel like they're in some European palace. Overall, the hotel has an Asian vibe but the swimming pool exerted more of a romantic, Western ambience. I don't know about anything else, but the pictures here would look amazing. The fitness center also looked great. Because of the tall ceiling I didn't even notice that it didn't have windows. That's how roomy it is to exercise there. It is filled with machines useful for daily fitness. There is an additional fee, but there is a screen golf center as well. The swimming pool and fitness center are top-class compared to any other hotel in Seoul. The breakfast buffet is at Tavolo 24, at the second floor. Dongdaemun is seen best from this location so the vibe the location has is great and the Korean food it serves is also eye-opening. There are a lot of types of tasty food that make it just as good as Seoul's top three buffets and it doesn't go too overboard so I was personally very happy with the breakfast there. Because the hotel itself provides lots of rooms with the option to use the Executive Lounge I imagine a lot of guests will use the club lounge at the 10th floor. The lounge isn't next-level amazing but it isn't that bad either. I don't think there is enough hot food to eat dinner there during Happy Hour but having snacks here and there will make you full. I wouldn't call it a gourmet restaurant but people can fill their stomachs here. The breakfast here is quite simple, which is characteristic of a lounge buffet but the view that can be seen from the outdoor area is beautiful, so I do recommend it. It'd be nice to visit once during your stay. Other than that, there's BLT Steakhouse which sells Korean-style steak The Lounge, which is famous for its strawberry buffet and afternoon tea The Griffin, a rooftop bar great to enjoy a drink with the Dongdaemun view Seoul Baking Company the bakery in the basement, and more. There are various food and beverage areas available for use. What is DDN's overall review of JW Marriott Dongdaemun? I'd say it was nice that it was near Dongdaemun but also had its downsides too. This hotel's biggest strength is that guests can view our number one national treasure up close. That's why the hotel's name has Dongdaemun in it and it is evident that the interior design was inspired by Dongdaemun as well. But because this is an old city center it's quite outdated, and there's not much to see so the fact that the hotel is located here makes it a bit weird to go there for a hocance if I may be very honest. The rooms that show Dongdaemun Market are comparatively much less satisfactory than the standards one would expect from a five-star hotel or a JW Marriott. A lot of people who go on 'hocance' trips visit nearby shopping malls or restaurants too but Dongdaemun isn't that kind of place, which was a bit sad. But if we focus on the hotel itself the rooms are elegant, the facilities are amazing the food is satisfactory and the lounge isn't bad either so for those of you who like to go on 'hocance' vacations it'd be nice to go here sometime. This is just my personal opinion but compared to JW Marriott Seoul which is too old and only has nice food and beverage options I think JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square is much better. Speaking of JW Marriott I'm sure a lot of you are curious about JW Marriott Jeju as well. I booked a room and am waiting to go there so please wait just a little bit. One of the most important things about a hotel is the view, and a new hotel has appeared that will make the hearts of both the geeks and the view-obsessed flutter. Even the infinity pool with a view of the Han River is amazing. But are other features as great as the view? Which cancer did I pay for? Honestly, [Music] Hello, I am a Ttottonam. The hotel I will introduce today is Hotel Naru M Gallery, located at the northern end of Mapo Bridge. It is a hotel with an incredible view of the Han River that I would give 200 out of 100. There are four factors that make the view of M Galleria perfect. First, the hotel beach is a gangster. It is one of the hotels closest to the Han River among the Mongkapotels, and it is a big advantage that the Han River can be seen right in front of the hotel without any obstructions. The second factor that is even more important is the direction the hotel building faces. Usually, buildings with a view of the Han River are parallel to the Han River, so they face the Han River head-on. Unlike the M Gallery, which is located at the intersection at the northern end of Mapo Bridge, it inevitably faces the Han River at a 45-degree angle. That is why the already wide width of the Han River  It opens up a much wider field of vision. Also, because it faces west, you can perfectly enjoy Seoul's beautiful sunset. However, no matter how beautiful the river is, if you look at it for too long, it tends to feel flat. However, the view of the Han River from MGallery is not just a view of the Han River, but a much more diverse one as it embraces various landmarks. First, Bamseom, one of the few islands on the Han River, comes into view at a glance, and across the river, you can even see the skyscrapers of Yeouido. Mapo Bridge and Gangbyeonbuk-ro, which are like arteries of Seoul, with their constant flashes of light, play a role in bringing the view to life. And finally, the hotel is well aware of the advantages of this view and has maximized it in the design of its space. More than half of the rooms face the Han River, and there is an infinity pool with a Han River view that was never seen before. You can easily enjoy a perfect view from the hotel lobby, restaurant, or anywhere else. So, what do you think? Do you agree that it is a view that is enough to capture the heart of a nerd? Now, let's take a closer look at the hotel. Hotel Naru MGallery is a luxury boutique brand that corresponds to the premium class of the past 10 [Music]. There is also a hotel. Because it's located in Mapo-Naru, it's named Hotel Naru MGallery. The hotel is a three-minute walk from Exit 4 of Mapo Station. However, because it's located at the Mapo Bridge intersection, it can be a bit tricky to get to the hotel by car. Valet parking is required, which is quite expensive. This location was originally the headquarters of Poongdong Co., Ltd., one of Korea's top three fertilizer companies. Poongdong also owns Korea's MGallery. The hotel building has a unique, open-center structure, with the right side being an officetel building operated completely separately from the hotel. The first floor, known as the "bedroom," serves as a welcome lounge where guests are greeted. Check-in is on the 20th floor. When the elevator doors open, you'll find a circular flowerbed, lush greenery, and a sculpture by Yang Ui-gyu hanging from the ceiling. The breathtaking view of the Han River outside the window doesn't draw much attention to the artwork. The high ceilings on the first floor, combined with the full-length windows, offer a breathtaking panoramic view of the Han River. The check-in counter and waiting area are located in front of the reception area. The place is not as big as you might think, but it is decorated with a decent modern feel. MGallery has five types of standard rooms and four types of suites. Let's first take a look at the Premier River Room, which has the best view of the Han River among the standard rooms. Entering through the arched hallway, you will find the bedroom. The room is clean and warm. The light wood-toned floor is neat and tidy without carpet, and the walls and furniture are decorated in white or neutral colors. The dark colors on the sofa, table, and bottom of the wall are used partially, making the neutral colors stand out even more. The simple design of the room is probably because one wall is occupied by a gorgeous view. This is the view of the Han River from the 17th floor. The view of the Han River from the room is also amazing. Since it is in the West, the afternoon sunlight is strong and it is a bit hot, but it is a view that you cannot give up. In fact, the Premier River Room and the Deluxe River Room are exactly the same room, and the only difference is the floor. This is the view of the Han River from the 12th floor, a Deluxe River Room. The view from the 12th floor is not bad, but it is definitely better to take in more of the Han River from a higher place. One drawback is that  If I had to pick one thing, the sofa was quite awkwardly positioned for a view of the Han River from bed. I wondered if it would have been better if it had been positioned facing the work table. The hotel is so obviously focused on tourism that there isn't much difference between the room sizes, but if you want to feel more relaxed, the 125 line might be a better option. The bathroom, decorated with bright marble, is compact and tightly divided, with a single sink, a separate toilet, and even a bathtub. The green tiles behind the bathtub add a touch of character, and bath salts are provided. However, in a round bathtub of this size, you can't stretch your legs. While it looks pretty, it's not practical. Amenities include reusable containers of Grow Alchemist products from the Australian natural cosmetics brand. A beautifully curved minibar offers capsule coffee and Althaus tea, along with a variety of cups and a coffee pot. The hallway near the entrance has a luggage storage area and a closet. As you've seen inside Winnie the Pooh, the hotel uses orange throughout. You'll find it in down jackets, slippers, and even the welcome card. For a higher vantage point, consider staying in the Premier River Suite. There are six rooms, three per floor, on the 24th floor, with separate living and bedrooms. At 63 square meters, the space is certainly spacious, so the windows are larger and the same Han River view seems much larger. A table is also provided for Ae-myung to sit at. Like the standard rooms you saw earlier, the suites are neat and tidy, with subtle touches here and there, showcasing a design that everyone will love. The inner bedroom has a bed and a table. Unlike the standard rooms, there's no long sofa in front of the window, so the Han River view is much more open. The stand design is also thoughtfully designed, befitting a suite. Passing through the luggage storage area, you'll find the bathroom, which is much larger, with two sinks. While it might be a bit small to stretch your legs out in, it also has a larger bathtub than the standard rooms. As a suite, there's a second guest bathroom at the entrance, and a styler is also included. The Bamseom Suite is a higher-end suite with a two-way view of the hotel. The living room is even larger than the standard suite, and the Han River view from there is trulyspectacular. It even has a large sofa and a six-person table, making it ideal for parties or VIPs.  It looks perfect for small events. The atmosphere continues from the standard rooms, but the furniture adds a touch of flair. On the opposite side is the bedroom, with a unique stand-up TV in front of the window. Finally, there's a bathroom with a long bathtub where you can stretch your legs. The bedroom faces the back of the hotel building, with a view of Namsan Mountain. I thought I'd see an apartment complex around Mapo Station in the back, but I can see Namsan Mountain from afar. Unusually, you can also see Lotte Tower across the Han River. The hotel is capitalizing on this by promoting Namsan Mountain as a view from rooms at the back, where the Han River is not visible. The Premier Namsan Room you're looking at now has a view of Namsan Mountain alongside the apartment complex. The room is a bit smaller, but it has a sofa and table in front of the bed, so it could be an option for those who want to sit and watch TV. Unusually, the Namsan View Room at the back has a bathtub with a shower booth, but instead has a larger bathtub. The last room you'll see is the Family Twin, a family room. It 's located only on the third floor of the hotel, and as expected from a family room, it has a thick double bed. A total of four people, including children and adults, can stay there. However, because it's on the third floor, the hotel's biggest advantage is that it has a sofa and table in front of the bed, so it could be an option for those who want to sit and watch TV.  The Han River view is a bit disappointing. Hotel Naru M Gallery has many auxiliary facilities and sign shops that take advantage of the view. Let 's take a look at the swimming pool, which you're probably most curious about. The outdoor infinity pool on the 20th floor, which was also featured in the video thumbnail, is truly a legendary swimming pool. Of course, like most infinity pools in the city, it's not the perfect size for swimming. It looks quite large, but about a third is a shallow space for sunbeds, and the actual immersion space is about two-thirds of the front. However, this place is originally meant for immersing yourself and admiring the scenery rather than swimming. Moreover, since the officetel is located at the top, the view is close to the south, facing Yeouido. It even served as a hidden harp when the fireworks festival was held in Yeouido not long ago. The infinity pool, which allows you to see the Han River from west to east at a glance, is a view that makes you proud to be a Seoul citizen, and a view that would rival any other in the world. However, it is currently scheduled to operate only until December, and it is said to be closed for a while during the winter and reopen next spring. Fortunately, the indoor pool, which is open even in the middle of winter, has a panoramic view. The view of the Han River from the window is just as good as that of the outdoor pool. It 's a bit narrow, but it's 25 meters long, and there's a shallow children's pool at one end. Not only are the arched pillars surrounding the pool, but mirrors are hung on the ceiling to reflect the pool. It's not a particularly fancy pool, but it's a clean and well-designed space. The fitness center is located in the back, out of sight, but the high ceilings make it feel comfortable. While the equipment isn't extensive, it has everything you need, including cardio equipment and power racks. Let's take a look at the Sig restaurant, which has a view as beautiful as the infinity pool. The French restaurant Buhajaeng, located on the 22nd floor, also serves breakfast. You can see the Han River from any table. The inner space, in particular, offers a full view of Yeouido toward the 63 Building, making it a hidden gem for the fireworks festival. The river view diminishes at night, so I personally recommend going for lunch or around sunset rather than dinner. I had dinner here with friends, and honestly, the food and service were a bit disappointing compared to the view.  I thought about it. Breakfast is also served at Buhajaeng. They take your coffee order upon seating. You can order egg dishes or waffles at your table. I ordered a waffle, but it was really lacking. I usually like crispy waffles, but I really enjoyed them. The buffet menu is also quite excellent. Of course, it may have opened early, but the menu composition and the taste of the food were all excellent. At the entrance to Buhajaeng, there is Buhajaeng, a bar that is popular among hotel guests. They say it is decorated with the concept of a herbal medicine store. In fact, if they didn't explain it, it would be hard to tell that it is Korean, but after hearing the explanation, there are traditional patterns here and there. The lobby where check-in is done has a lounge and deck. It is not a large space, but thanks to the high-rise building and the amazing view, the atmosphere is just like that of a large hotel lounge. You can have afternoon tea or light alcoholic beverages here. Finally, there is Cafe Mapo A on the first floor. This is not a hotel facility, but a casual cafe and bakery that the general public can use comfortably. So, what would be the overall review of Hotel Naro M Gallery? The most perfect.  This is the best hotel in Seoul, boasting a view of the Han River. I've praised it as much as I did the Evie Plaza before, but the view alone is truly the best in Seoul and rivals any hotel in the world. While I had expected the view to some extent, I was pleasantly surprised by how good the overall hotel design was. The overall design of the hotel doesn't seem to be overly hip, but rather subdued, yet still manages to capture the essence. Anyone can tell that this place has a great atmosphere and is well-decorated. The guest rooms have beautiful views, the breakfast is delicious, and the pool is nice. In fact, Dosi Mokangs has almost everything. However, because it's a boutique hotel, it lacks the grandeur and grandeur of a five-star hotel like the Conrad or Fairmont across the street. When you actually go there, you might find it a bit smaller than you'd expect. It seems to compete with the two hotels in Yeouido facing the Han River, but I personally don't think the Conrad or Fairmont can compete with the view at all. If I had to choose one of the three, I would definitely choose the MGallery. However, the two hotels in Yeouido definitely have a strong presence, as do the guest rooms.  It's spacious and the interior is much more luxurious. It's also good for a water vacation, but in this respect, you might feel that the MGallery is a little boring. Anyway, the MGallery is a great hotel that appeared in the middle of Seoul unexpectedly, and I definitely want to visit this hotel again. If today's video was helpful for your trip, please subscribe, like, and set notifications. In the next video, I'll be back with a review of Singapore Airlines, one of the top airlines in the world. The LOTTE World Tower is the tallest in South  Korea and the 5th tallest in the entire world. It is a shining beacon, a symbol of the city of  Seoul. If you were to Google Seoul right now, it's probably one of the first images that  comes up. The mega-conglomerate LOTTE decided to build an ultra-luxury hotel at the very  top of this tower from floors seventy six to a hundred and seven. They brought in a  three Michelin-starred chef from France, a world class service team and top  contemporary artists from Asia and called it The Signiel. It is a Leading  Hotel of the World, classified as six stars and quickly is becoming one of the very  best. So of course I had to do a full review! I reviewed out of 50 points in five categories.  The categories are The Ambiance, The Room, The Dining, The Service and The It-Factor.  It’s hard to explain what it is like to stay a hundred stories up in the air, so let’s  start on the ground floor and work our way up. This is the ground floor of the LOTTE  Tower. This is really the only thing on floor one. It’s not technically part of  the hotel. It’s across the street from LOTTE World, which is like Korea’s Disney  land which after doing some digging I’ve realized that LOTTE owns a lot of South  Korea; from malls, to amusement parks and this tower itself. So Signiel is their  luxury property, and from what I can tell, they pulled out all of the stops to make this  exceptional. I mean just look at this entrance. Look at this. This is the lobby for the  Signiel Hotel. So on my left we have the check in desk and concierge. On my right is a  high-end pastry shop where they’re literally encased in glass. You can see that no expense  has been spared in building this and designing it. In-fact, they brought in some well-known  artists: my favorite piece is the chandelier here which is called "An Aggregation". Just an  incredible lobby but for now let’s keep going up. So up on the 85th floor is a full  pool overlooking the city. You literally are swimming in the sky. And over here there’s a  full cold-plunge pool which if you’ve seen any of my other videos on the channel like Hotel  Bel-Air or The Ritz Carlton in Puerto Rico, you’ll know I have to try this a little bit later. A little higher up now is The Retreat Spa at  the Signiel. It is one of the most minimalistic and aesthetically pleasing spas that I have seen.  They even have an oil atelier that helps you pick the oils before your treatment. Now you might  know that Korea is famous for its skin care, its hair care, so we had to stop the tower  climb and give these treatments a try. So I’m getting the Korean skin care treatment  and hair treatment today, it's 90 minutes. That was insane. It was a multi-step facial and hair cleansing treatment.  Alright let’s keep going. Alright so we are high enough now that you  can really get that panoramic view of Seoul right below the tower is the Han River  and this is the Salon de Signiel which is a library you can sit, order a coffee, read  your books and know that you are higher than 99.9% of the rest of the world. So it's  not the dining segment yet but they have two different beans here, it's 79 and  123 named after the floors in the tower. So good, and it’s gonna motivate  me to go work out, so let’s go see the gym. Okay, so those are the public spaces here  at the Signiel. But overall, everything is very well designed and very very clean.  It feels like a brand new hotel. The gym is excellent and well appointed, the spa is  very aesthetic, although minimalistic, even so it still has that kind of cold and corporate  feel, which you just get being in a sky scraper. So we’ve seen some better decor in other  hotels. It's a relatively small hotel with the floors they have, but they make good use of the  space that they do have. I gave The Ambience an 8/10. Now let’s get out of this  ice pool and continue our journey up the tower. There are 235 rooms at  The Signiel ,and I got one of the highest because you have to see the view from the bathroom. So I  don't normally start with the bathroom, but come on you have to when you have a view like this  from the bathtub. The bathroom feels a lot like the rest of The Signiel, which is a ton of granite,  very modern, clean lines, the lighting is excellent. Fades on when you turn it on, fades off. Introducing a special hotel located just a 5-minute walk from SinNonhyeon Station in the trendy Gangnam area of South Korea! This hotel offers great value with breakfast, sauna, and even free late-night snacks, making it a popular choice for both locals and foreigners. When we visited in February 2025 on a weekend, the price for a room with breakfast for two was around 200,000 KRW. This hotel is part of the Japanese Kyoritsu Group chain, known for its meticulous attention to detail and friendly service that reflects Japan’s hospitality culture. At the lobby, they offer unlimited welcome drinks, along with a coffee machine, tea bags, ice, and water dispenser, providing various convenient amenities. There’s also a computer and printer available for business travelers, making it convenient to get work done. The hotel has a total of 220 rooms, and when we visited, it was fully booked, reflecting its high popularity. While the room we stayed in wasn’t very large, the spacious window design made it comfortable and airy. Considering its location in Gangnam, we found the size and price to be reasonable. Inside the room, you'll find indoor wear and slippers for use at the hot springs, and the bed features a Simmons mattress made in Japan, ensuring a comfortable night's sleep. The bathroom is small but well-designed, with a powerful shower and splash-proof design, showcasing the hotel’s attention to detail. Additionally, it supports both 220V and 110V outlets, making it very convenient to use electronic devices. However, one downside to the room was the light from the switch next to the bed, which could be a little bothersome during sleep. The highlight of the hotel is the Japanese-style hot spring located on the basement floor. The large bath with artificial hot spring water includes a healing spa and sauna, with separate male and female baths. After enjoying the hot springs, you can indulge in free late-night ramen (yonaki soba) served from 9PM to 10:30PM—perfect to end your day. The breakfast, while not quite on the level of a luxury hotel, is substantial enough to start your day. The grilled white fish and probiotic drink were particularly impressive, and the freshness of the ingredients was satisfying. If you're looking to relax in a hot spring, enjoy a hearty breakfast, and experience all this at a reasonable price in the heart of Gangnam, don't miss the special experience at Dormy Inn Seoul Gangnam!

The first hotel in Korea opened in the 1880s at Jemulpo Port in Incheon. It was the Terry. Hotels targeting foreigners were built in Seoul and Incheon, but there are almost none left. These days, the oldest hotel in Korea, the Westin Chosun Seoul, still exists, even though it was built in 1914 by the Japanese Government-General of Korea's Railway Bureau. It is operated as the Westin Chosun Seoul. When it was first established, it was a four-story building with a land area of ​​6,700 pyeong and 60 guest rooms. After liberation, the Chosun Hotel was taken over by the South Korean government. In 1967, it signed a contract with Enamel Camera Line for the construction of a new hotel, and in 1970, it reopened as a hostel in its current form. That really is getting into now the It-Factor. The  It-Factor is that thing about a hotel you can't really explain, but it makes you want to keep  coming back. So the Four Seasons here is actually built on top of an ancient street from the Josun  Dynasty, they've preserved that street and in the basement of the hotel through the glass here, you  can actually see the original street, with some informational cards and some descriptions of what  you're looking at. An amazing feature to highlight the history of the hotel. So because we have seen  other properties that just have more of a tie-in to the place where they're located, or have  something more unique or interesting about the property, I gave the It-Factor a 6.5/10. Hello guys! welcome back to foo dojo In today’s video, I will be showing you guys  one of my favorite Hotel in Gangnam Seoul Korea The name of the hotel is voco hotel Seoul  Gangnam by InterContinental Hotels Group. Located in Seoul's lively Gangnam  district, which is brimming with exciting tourist attractions, and business centers. It is also known as one of the richest districts in South Korea and is home to many department  stores, underground shopping centers, and malls. This is where you would find Louis Vuitton,  Chanel, Versace, and other designer stores. The nearest tourist spots are Garosugil 0.3km, Hyundai Department Store 1.3km,  and Apgujeong Rodeo Street 1.7km. Now let’s go inside the hotel The lobby looks like this and there is a  restaurant behind the counter called Amarillo. Amarillo, their all-day dining  restaurant, serves international fusion cuisine for breakfast, lunch, and  dinner, as well as delightful cocktails. The check-in time is 3 pm but I was able to check  in at 11 am because of gold member benefits. You could also do an early check-in for a charge. Now let’s go to the room. We had to reserve two rooms for  this stay because it was full. But both of the room was on the 9th  floor so it was easy to switch rooms This is Our first room. a Premium One King Bed with Bathtub. This is a 30 square meters Premium room with  a king-size bed, city views, high-speed Wi-Fi, a complimentary Minibar, 55-inch smart TV,  and a bathroom with a rain shower and bathtub. From the window, you can see the main  street, Namsan Tower, and the river, You can also go to Garosugil in less  than 5 minutes so it was a great location The closet has bathrobes and slippers, There is a free mini bar in the room  where you can enjoy free crackers, drip coffee, hot chocolate, and tea in the refrigerator, there are also beer,  rice beer, water, sparkling water and juices. all room comes with these free snacks and drinks. and are replenished daily. There was no coffee machine in the  room but the hotel had a room services and there were many convenience store and cafes  near by the hotel so it wasn’t a big deal! The hotel also has Buffet style  breakfast from 06:30am to 10:30am. unfortunately, our plan didn’t include  the buffet but it is available at the cafe/restaurant behind the check in counter. This is the premium bathroom The toilet has a washlet And  the Amenities include shaving, shoe shine, nail set, comb,  toothbrush and many more Now let's check the hotel facilities. First and foremost, each level has a guest  kitchen where visitors can enjoy cooking! This shared kitchen was incredibly useful  when I was cooking late-night meals, and it is also where you can get ice as well! The hotel also includes a common laundry area. For 1000won, detergent and  dry sheets were provided. Finally, there is the Fitness Center. It is open between 12:00 AM and 12:00 AM. There were free weights, a stationary bicycle,  a treadmill, and other machines accessible. i was surprised by this machine because  this had all Pull, Push and leg capability. Now lets go see our second room. we Moved from number 907 to number 909. Our new room was right infant of  our old one so it was very easy. This is a twin bed room The room looks like this,  the structure is the same, but it is slightly smaller than the previous room. Instead of a sofa, it becomes a table and chair,  and the view becomes the scenery behind the hotel. You can see the convenience  store in the parking lot below. Drinks and all the amenities are also the same. The bathroom has a rain shower and hand shower. Our old room had no shower curtain when  using the bathtub, so the floor got wet, which was quite inconvenient. So if you want to relax in the bathtub,  I recommend the premium bathroom, but if you want to just shower, I recommend  reserving the normal shower room. Overall, the room was comfortable and  clean, and the hotel was conveniently located near the local subway station  so it was very easy to go around Seoul Everyone at the front desk was really kind and  helpful, and despite being on the main street, the hotel was very peaceful,  so I had no trouble sleeping. Although there was a convenience store close, running errands was inconvenient at  times, so I appreciated having a minibar. There was also a park nearby, which allowed  me to relax comfortably from the morning. For that reason I will  definitely come to visit again! I highly recommend staying at VOCO  Seoul Gangnam if you are looking for a hotel in a great location with  nearby services and a subway station! Thank you guys for watching If you liked today’s video, Please like and subscribe and click  the bell icon to get new video updates! Also, make sure to check  out my other videos as well! Chao see you next time

South Korea is quickly becoming one of the hottest  travel destinations as the world has been swooning over all things Korean the ever famous Korean  skincare routine K-pop bands or just the amazing Korean cuisine there is no better time to dust  off your passport and book the next flight to South Korea now the next question is where should  you stay welcome back luxury Travelers today we're taking you on a journey to explore the top five  most exclusive hotels in South Korea along with the best dining and entertainment options and as  a bonus we'll even reveal a secret luxury hotel shrouded in Parisian Mystique so sit back relax  and get ready to be enchanted by South Korea's finest accommodations coming in at number five is  the suniel Busan located in the beautiful coastal city of Busan this incredible hotel is part of  the senior brand which is known for offering unparalleled luxury from the moment you step  into the lobby you'll be greeted by stunning ocean views and Sleek modern Decor the hotel's 260  guest rooms and Suites offer panoramic views of both the city and the ocean and are equipped with  the latest technology to ensure a comfortable stay there are many amazing accommodation options but  for those who want the ultimate luxury experience the Grand Suite is the perfect choice this room  offers a stunning view of Honda Beach and features a king-size bed a dining room and a massive  bathroom one of the standout features of signal Busan is its luxurious Spa which offers a range  of treatments and services to help guests unwind and rejuvenate the spa features a hydrotherapy  pool sauna and steam room as well as private treatment rooms where you can indulge in a massage  or facial South Koreans have mastered the art of beauty treatments and you'll leave the spa feeling  reborn signal Busan has you covered if you're in the mood for some retail therapy South Koreans are  Infamous for their stylish fashion and the hotel is situated in the center of the busy Hyundai  neighborhood home to a wide variety of upscale stores and boutiques as well as outdoor markets  we guarantee that you'll find an amazing outfit Busan is the ideal place to begin exploring the  many cultural Treasures that South Korea and Busan has to offer several of the city's most well-known  attractions like the Magnificent Hindi Beach and the Charming gamcion cultural Village are  conveniently close to the hotel we also recommend a visit to the biomiosa temple an ancient Buddhist  place of worship located at the foot of a mountain the sineyal Busan is a must visit for anyone  looking to experience the amazing city of Busan and enjoy the finest of Korean Hospitality however  no visit to South Korea would be perfect without a visit to the nation's capital the city of Seoul  get ready for some Gangnam Style number four on our list is the Grand Hyatt Soul situated in  the heart of the famous Gangnam District the hotel boasts a prime location with easy access to  some of seoul's top attractions the hotel's Grand Lobby sets the tone for the luxurious experience  that awaits guests with its highest highest marble floors and grand staircase you'll feel like you've  stepped into a palace the rooms and Suites are equally impressive featuring elegant Decor plush  bedding and panoramic city views the hotel has a total of 601 rooms each designed to provide  the ultimate comfort and luxury for its guests the ultimate luxury experience the penthouse suite  is the perfect option for the picky tourist the suite offers stunning panoramic views of the  city skyline in Han River a private Terrace with a jacuzzi a separate living room bedroom and  a luxurious bathroom with a separate shower and bathtub one of the standout features of Grand  Hyatt soul is its extensive range of dining options the hotel has a total of nine restaurants  and bars we highly recommend a visit to tepan a restaurant that specializes in fine modern Korean  cuisine and offers a culinary journey of South Korea through their tasting menu honoring  the country's traditions and local produce in addition to the amazing food diners can also  gaze out at the scenic view of Namsan Mountain through the restaurant's wide Windows the hotel  is conveniently located in the Gangnam goo area seoul's upscale modern Center home to gleaming  skyscrapers designer Brands and stylish nightclubs where big name DJ's spin techno and house music  dining options span high-end restaurants to bars but to really feel the pulse of Soul go for a  local serving of Korean fried chicken and Soju rice wine if you're looking to explore the area  you can also visit the Namsan Tower the national museum of Korea and the Gangnam District's famous  coax Mall the Grand Hyatt soul is undoubtedly one of the best choices for those looking to  experience luxury and exclusivity in the heart of seoul's vibrant Gangnam District but if you're  looking to relax in luxurious surroundings while enjoying Korean culture the next on our list  might be perfect for you moving on to number three on our list we have the Shila Jeju situated  on the picturesque island of JeJu this hotel is a true Oasis of luxury and relaxation the hotel's  design is inspired by the natural beauty of Jeju island with each room offering stunning views  of the surrounding landscape the luxury resort features 429 rooms and Suites all of which are  designed to provide the ultimate comfort and relaxation one of the things that set the Shila  teju apart from other hotels is its commitment to promoting Korean culture and traditions guests  can take part in various cultural experiences such as tea ceremonies National Korean paper making  workshops a stay at the Shila Jeju requires a visit to the beautiful halasan National Park the  area offers stunning hiking trails and a chance to see the famous Bangkok Dam Crater Lake which lies  inside a dormant volcano the local says that the volcano represents the virtues of a Korean mother  being both Fierce and gentle the Shila cheju truly embodies the spirit of Korea a perfect choice for  any luxury traveler looking to explore Korea's Rich culture and amazing nature but if you're  looking for a pulsing City vacation in some of the most exclusive surroundings imaginable the next  on our list will make you reach for your passport number two the lotta Hotel Seoul our second most  exclusive Hotel on this list is the epitome of Korean Elegance located in the heart of seoul's  bustling City Center this hotel offers guests a perfect mix of modern luxury and traditional  Korean hospitality upon arrival guests are greeted by a striking lobby with high ceilings elaborate  chandeliers and a grand piano the hotel's design reflects traditional Korean elements such as  the use of warm wood and stone blended with contemporary art and architecture the hotel boasts  over 1 000 rooms and Suites which are all spacious and stylishly decorated with The property has 462 rooms  across 20 floors and is conveniently located in Myeongdong, within walking  distance of many popular attractions. This is the lobby and front desk area. I liked these elevators because they take you to your room’s floor just by tapping your room key - a convenient feature. This is a 1 King Deluxe Guest  Room. On the right is the bathroom. The mirror spans the entire wall which  looks pretty cool. There is a bidet toilet. In the corner, there is a box of  toiletries and a seemingly normal drawer, but it actually swivels open. On the right is the shower/bath tub. The shower  head height is adjustable and can be handheld. There is a robe on the back of the door.  And the most interesting feature in the bathroom is this emergency call button. Hmm… haha. Back by the entryway, there are storage  closets with awkward pins for handles. This closet has a second robe, slippers, an  umbrella, and even a shoe horn which is nice to see - very useful. This is the main part of the  room, there is a TV, work desk, small loveseat, and a king size bed. In the entertainment  center, there is drinkware and Nespresso pods. some snacks and drinks for  purchase, and a mini fridge. Beside the TV is the Nespresso machine  and water bottles without labels. This is our city view. This is the most functional bedside control panel  I have ever seen in a hotel. There are the usual light controls, then climate control which is  rare, and then seven outlets. At that point, I wouldn’t have enough cables to utilize them  all. But they are there if you need them. There is a traditional thermostat on the wall. You can display a red “do not disturb” or a blue “please clean our room” light outside the front door with buttons from inside the room. This is the fitness center, it  is a really big fitness center for a hotel of any size. The free weights  and weight machines are by the entrance. Then there is a seemingly  endless row of cardio machines. Then along the back wall, there are a few  other machines and some inversion machines which is pretty cool to see. There are  towels and chilled water on this wall. This is the indoor pool. The left lane is for  swimming laps and the right is for wading. Off to the side are the pool chairs,  cabanas for rent, and two small jacuzzis. Between the pool and gym, there are sauna  rooms. The property also has a salon and spa. I wasn’t allowed to film in the Westin Club  Lounge, but here are images from The Westin’s website. The Club Lounge is on the 20th and  highest floor of the hotel which offers great views of Seoul’s cityscape. It is open everyday  from 7am to 9pm. They serve breakfast in the morning, snacks and desserts in the afternoon,  and dinner and drinks in the evening. Lounge access can be purchased when booking your  room which usually costs an additional $50 per night. Lounge access is complimentary for  those with Marriott Platinum status or higher. Westin’s Lounge & Bar on the  1st floor offers afternoon tea and cocktails with a view of a scenic shrine. On the lower level, there is Chosun Deli. Ok. Westin Restaurant Lightning Round. There are five sit-down restaurants; Hong Yuan, a cantonese restaurant, Sushi Cho, a japanese restaurant. The Ninth Gate, an American restaurant. RUBRICA, an Italian restaurant. And Aria, their buffet. Excuse the shakiness, I didn’t have my gimbal at the time. This is the Aria buffet during breakfast. The first station had super unique  pastries. There was a counter around the corner that had toast, bagels, and jams. This island  station has soup, congee, and Korean side dishes. There is a coffee station which always  garners a line, followed by dim sum. I think this end was for udon. This station had American breakfast staples:  french toast, waffles, and pancakes. This end had fried rice, bulgogi, salmon, and tofu.  There was an omelet station, next to that were eggs and breakfast meats. The middle island had an  assortment of fruit, vegetables, yogurts, cereals, juices, cold meats, salad, and pastas. Overall,  an impressive spread. Pro Tip: Complimentary Aria breakfast is a welcome amenity option for  those with Marriott Platinum status or higher. Ok. Something new that I will include in my videos  is a simple rating of the hotel and their value proposition as it allows me to add something  unique to these videos and gives a reference for which to compare future hotels. These ratings are  based entirely on my opinions and experiences, and are subjective as there are no equations involved.  Anyways, I hope you find the ratings helpful. For the room, 4 out of 5 for its cleanliness,  functionality, and comfort. For functionality, recall light and climate control, and an  unusual amount of ports by the bedside, surprising amount of storage, nespresso  machine, advanced toilet, and adjustable shower head. And for comfort, there was  a loveseat which usually aren’t found in baserooms. The only drawback was that the room is  on the small side, coming in at under 400 sq ft. I think The Westin Josun Seoul’s amenities are a  5 out of 5. The property has a picturesque pool, a large gym, sauna, spa, salon, 5 upscale  restaurants, a club lounge, a bar, a deli, a wine shop, and venue space for business  meetings or weddings. The amenities are as plentiful as they are high quality.  So, easy 5 out of 5 in this category. Intangibles consists of location, service, and  any unique factors such as historical significance or styling and decor - the soft product sort-of  speak. The Westin Josun Seoul scores a 5 out of 5 in this category. The location of the property  is ideal, in walking distance to Namsan Tower, popular shopping and dining, historical landmarks,  and a 10 minute bus ride from Seoul Station. The property has a lot of historical significance  as Korea’s oldest luxury hotel. And the customer service is excellent - they helped us hail  taxis which can be difficult for non-Korean residents and Jessie Park secured a salon  reservation even after we checked out. The staff was fluent in English. I know this  is a very American comment, but imagine how inconvenient it would be to stay at a hotel  where you cannot communicate with the staff. Moving on to the cash value.  When we booked for September, room rates were about $200 per night  which I think is an amazing value. When you compare that to some of the lower quality  hotels in America that go for higher rates, this is a no-brainer. Pretty much  a “take my money” kind of deal. The Westin Josun Seoul is a part of Marriott’s  loyalty program which has dynamic pricing for award nights. When we booked, the award  nights were 38,000 to 40,000 Marriott points per night which I think makes for an excellent  redemption. Great point value to be had here. Overall, The Westin Josun Seoul is  a luxury hotel in every regard and offers excellent value when  booking with cash or points. Ok, that is all for my review of The  Westin Josun Seoul. Thanks for joining.
