It’s hard to go wrong with a Park Hyatt, but that doesn’t necessarily mean it’s going to be that exciting either. Hi there, my name is Kevin. This channel came from a love of traveling, a love of the full process and the journey itself. I feature airline trip reports and high end hotel reviews from all over the world. My reviews aren’t sponsored by airlines or hotels so you can be sure to get my unbiased honest opinion. Am I an expert? You can decide. Am I fair? Yea, I am. Let’s get into it, welcome to Seoul. If you’d like to know the exact nightly rate that I paid for my stay or my next five videos in queue, please check out the description below. I just arrived on Air Premia from Saigon and am now heading to check in. While many Park Hyatts are known for their grand spaces, the Park Hyatt Seoul is decidedly understated and discreet- perhaps too much as I think the strangest feature about this property is its entrance. On the ground floor we just have the small drive way and very small elevator lobby which will take you up to the 24th floor where the lobby is. This is common when a hotel needs to share a building, but this hotel, originally opened in 2005, takes up the entire building. When you get off of the elevators on the 24th floor, the top floor, you walk head on into a small reception area that you see here. Attached to the lobby is the lounge named, The Lounge. Serving meals throughout the day and afternoon tea, it is a tastefully decorated but it is quite small. For a Park Hyatt with 184 rooms, I honestly cannot think of why the layout of his hotel is how it is. Let’s quickly talk about the hotel’s location. The Park Hyatt is in the south east of the city, in the eastern part of the famous Gangnam district, but the specific location itself is not exactly bustling. It is directly across the street from the COEX mall and there is an entrance to the Samseong Metro station just in front of the hotel. I’ll hold judgment on the location and say, it’s either a good base to rely on the metro, or you have specific things in the area you plan to visit. So, one thing that I didn’t actually know about the property while I was there was it’s age. All research I do about hotels I do after my stay unless there’s some significant historical story that’s worth knowing. Generally I like to experience a hotel as any typical guest would- not knowing the year it was built or the original designers, which in this case is the Japanese firm, Super Potato who have worked on a litany of hotels in the region for the likes of Park Hyatt, Rosewood, Conrad, Andaz and more. But so anyway, the age. For a hotel that is 18 years old, it’s looking pretty good. Some of the common spaces like the lounge were refreshed during covid, but the rooms look just about the same as when it first opened and they still look really good and dare I say, current. I booked with AMEX Fine Hotels and was offered an upgraded room upon checking in, in this case, bumped up two categories essentially raising the floor and improving the view. Note that, to get to my room on the 15th floor, you would need to go up to the lobby level, change elevators and come back down to floor 15. The layout of the room is a bit odd but I actually kinda like it. The decor inside is simple and the tone of orange wood does date it a little bit, but not as much as I was expecting. Overall, it was a great first impression. A very small detail, but I was happy both sides of the bed had the same controls and also had USB C ports in addition to the universal plug. Generally the curtain and shade controls and often the master switch is only on one side of the bed, which always seemed odd to me. Park Hyatt beds are my favorite beds, so we also know that I slept pretty darn well while I was here. The only silly thing about the layout was that there were no power outlets near the table and chairs, just under the TV. For light sleepers, I’ll point out a sign which is on the table. It essentially says, we are happy to offer you floor to ceiling windows but that means that the noise level is unpredictable and we offer ear plugs on request. I thought this was a smart touch and personally I didn’t find the noise bleed particularly bad, it was just a very low urban hum, quite relaxing to me actually. The mini bar is very thoughtfully stocked, though of course we could do better than plastic water bottles- though at least it’s not Dasani. A pro Nespresso machine was on offer as well as Althaus teas. When I called to ask for two more Nespresso pods I swear my doorbell rang before I hung up the phone. What the service here lacked a bit in warmth it certainly made up for in poise and efficiency. The only annoying bit to me in the room is the closet which has one of the stupid triple sliding doors which means you can never see more than ⅓ of the closet at a time. The bathroom was impressive though. The design throughout the hotel is said to “balance design and luxury in a respectful, low key manner” and I think no place in the room fits that better than in the wet room. I would have guessed just based on the shower and tub area that the hotel was 2 or 3 years old. The fact that this is the original design from 18 years ago is impressive and I think speaks volumes about what Park Hyatt as a brand offers. Whether classic or modern in design, they are all in their own way timeless- or shall we say, more timeless than most hotels. Currently there are 46 Park Hyatt locations with three more opening soon and a few more in the extended pipeline. Park Hyatt is the flagship brand of the World of Hyatt group. Just realizing this as I write now, is in fact the flagship of their Timeless Collection of brands, so at least they are accurate with that one. In the bathroom you’ll find Le Labo Bergamont number 22 bath products. Now of course, given all of this glass, there are plenty of shades to give you privacy. So, beautiful rooms- who’s staying here? My guess is this is a very popular staycation hotel for locals and is convenient for anyone with business in the COEX area, beyond that, Park Hyatts will always attract quite a few World of Hyatt Loyalists. For me personally the only downside of the location is the distance from the airports, taking a solid hour to hour and a half driving. Let’s explore the other facilities on offer, heading first to the indoor pool which is connected by a small lounge area. As with the lobby lounge, I think the leisure facilities again feel quite limited- I think this can be attributed to the age of the hotel and maybe partially excused, but it does exclude the hotel from being a destination of it’s own. Given that, the pool is beautiful, day or night. Heading down from the pool is Citrus. On their website this is actually presented as an F&B venue, but in reality, it’s just a spa refreshment bar, if even that. Time for a beautiful sunset and then another shot that, let’s just say, took me a few takes. I really do love the look of the tower at night and think it has a decidedly modern facade. Ok, time for dinner and the first of three meals we’ll have here, starting at The Timber House. This restaurant and bar is located in the basement and is accessible from the ground floor lobby as well. The Timber House is said to be designed to resemble a post modern Hanok- or traditional Korean wooden house, with Korean wood tiles, patterned sliding doors and other complementing design accents. I generally really really don’t like basement food venues, but I’ve got to say, if it’s gotta be in the basement, this is the way to go. It is comfortable and cozy, warm and inviting and just makes you want to have a seat and sit back while sipping on something amber in color. The food here though, is a bit odd. There are two choices, the Harmony Course, which is a $100 set menu… or, an Izakaya themed Happy Hour menu. Not only do I think these two menus don’t really fit together, I also wish there was more Korean fare on any and all of the menus here in general. That said, the food was very good. I had a sashimi salad and a pork katsu sando on matcha bread- sounded really strange but was a really nice pairing actually. The next morning for breakfast we head to Cornerstone. This is the hotels all day dining venue serving up Italian fare. For breakfast though they put on a beautiful breakfast spread with a small supplemental menu as well. Really one of the better buffets I’ve had in a while, I especially loved the wide array of Korean dishes on offer. New trip, so let’s switch this up a bit. When creating a hotel or flight review, what do you think are some of the most important characteristics about those reviews? To me, to make a truly unbiased review, two things need to be true. First, I need to pay a fare or rate that is publicly available and receive no special treatment or compensation. Second, I need to film anonymously. If I reveal my identity today, that means an airline or a hotel might recognize me tomorrow and lay on the VIP treatment extra thick. I don’t want that. So rest assured that this video today is exactly what I say it is, an unbiased review. And that is why your likes, comments and subscriptions mean so much, they really do help the channel to grow and continue to put out this twice weekly and soon three times weekly content. My patreon is also linked below. And fig jam! One of my favorite things ever, I’ve never seen it at a hotel before. I had to get a piece of toast just to try it. The French Toast was also really good, grilled over charcoal and not too sweet. To work off all of those calories, was the nicely outfitted fitness center, but it along with the pool, was closed all day for cleaning. But, there was no cleaning being done and from my eyes, three different guests who were pretty pissed off that it was locked, with nothing actually being done. Anyway, last up, we have lunch at the Lounge. I chose one of the few Korean items, an Iberico Pork lunch set, from the menu and it was absolutely fantastic. I might not be a fan of the mix of dishes on the menus, but what they serve up they do really well. So, overall, it’s a very nice, buttoned up hotel which gives you everything you’d need, but nothing more- which I do think makes it a bit lacking for a Park Hyatt. Would I come back? Probably not, I’d rather try another place out, but if you need to be in this area, it is certainly a comfortable and delicious place to stay. I really do hope you enjoyed this video today, if you did, please click that thumbs up button and subscribe with notifications on, so you don’t miss any of the 21 hotels on this trip. I’ll see you next time from the Andaz Gangnam Seoul. Oh and thanks for watching until the end.

In this video, we will take a look at the five best hotels in Seoul, South Korea. I will leave links in the description for the best prices for each of these hotels, so make sure to check them out. At number five, we have Four Seasons Hotel Soul. Four Seasons Hotel Soul is the perfect spot for anyone looking to soak up the vibrant energy of the city while enjoying a slice of luxury. Nestled just steps away from Guang Huaman Plaza, this hotel offers stunning city views and is conveniently located near must-sea attractions like Yong Bokong Palace and Chongchon Stream. With five in-house dining options, guests can indulge in a delicious array of cuisines from Korean to Italian, making every meal an exciting experience. Plus, the sleek rooms come with floor to-seeiling windows that provide breathtaking views along with modern amenities like an iPad mini to make hotel services a breeze. What really sets Four Seasons Hotel Soul apart is its impressive range of facilities. Guests can unwind in traditional Korean sauners or hit the state-of-the-art fitness center, which even includes a unique indoor golf experience with 3D renditions of famous courses. The hotel's bar scene is also a highlight, perfect for enjoying a cocktail or sampling a fantastic selection of wines. With 24-hour reception and business services, plus free Wi-Fi, everything is designed for convenience and comfort. Whether it's a getaway for relaxation or a base for exploring the city, this hotel has something for everyone. At number four, we have the Schiller Soul. The Schiller Soul is a top-notch choice for anyone looking to experience the vibrant heart of Seoul. With its Forbes nominated five-star status, the hotel has consistently impressed guests with its exceptional service and luxurious amenities. The warm- colored rooms are not just cozy, they come equipped with everything from air conditioning to a mini bar, making it a perfect retreat after a long day of exploring the city. Plus, the free Wi-Fi means staying connected is a breeze. Guests can indulge in a variety of dining options from fine Korean cuisine at Laon to a mix of international flavors at the all-day dining restaurant. And let's not forget the refreshing cocktails served with live jazz at the librarian ideal spot to unwind. What really sets the Schiller Soul apart is its fantastic location in the central business district, making it super convenient for both business and leisure travelers. The hotel offers a free shuttle to nearby attractions like the Schilla duty-free shop and Donguk University Station, so getting around is easy. For those wanting to stay active, the fitness club is a standout feature. Boasting a gym, indoor golf range, and even yoga classes. Whether it's a luxurious stay, delicious dining, or a prime location, the Schilla Soul has everything needed for a memorable visit to Seoul. At number three, we have Signal Soul. Signal Soul is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to experience luxury in the heart of the city. Nestled between the 76th and 101st floors of the iconic Lotto World Tower, this five-star hotel offers stunning panoramic views of Seoul right from your room. With 235 beautifully appointed rooms featuring all the comforts like a mini bar, coffee machine, and flat screen TV, guests can unwind in style. Plus, the hotel's amenities are top-notch, including a Michelin starred restaurant, a chic champagne bar, and an inviting indoor swimming pool. The direct connection to Jamsil subway station makes it super easy to explore the city, making it a perfect base for both relaxation and adventure. What really sets Signal Soul apart is its incredible dining options and attentive service. Guests can indulge in authentic Korean cuisine at the award-winning Bicina or savor exquisite French dishes at the Stay restaurant helmed by a celebrated Michelin chef. The staff goes above and beyond with services like concierge assistance and valet parking ensuring a hassle-free stay. Whether it's lounging by the pool, enjoying a meal with a view, or simply soaking in the luxurious atmosphere, Signal Soul promises an unforgettable experience that's hard to beat in the bustling Yongyo district. At number two, we have Grand Hyatt Soul. Grand Hyatt Soul is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to enjoy a luxurious stay in the heart of the city. With its stunning views of either the bustling cityscape or the serene Namsan Mountain, the hotel offers a cozy escape right in the middle of all the action. The amenities are top-notch, featuring a refreshing ice skating rink and inviting swimming pools that make for a fun day without even leaving the hotel. Food lovers will appreciate the diverse dining options from a hearty buffet breakfast at the terrace to mouthwatering grilled dishes at the steakhouse. Plus, the location is super convenient, just a short drive from popular spots like Soul Station and Mongdong, making it easy to explore the vibrant local culture. What really sets Grand Hyatt Soul apart is its impressive recreation facilities. The Club Olympus is a haven for fitness enthusiasts, boasting tennis and squash courts, a welle equipped fitness center, and a relaxing sauna to unwind after a workout. For those looking to indulge, the spa offers a range of treatments, including traditional Korean massages and aromatherapy. With a Taiwan just a quick walk away and easy access to major business districts, this hotel is perfect for both leisure travelers and business visitors. Overall, Grand Hyatt Soul combines luxury, convenience, and a touch of fun, making it a standout option for anyone visiting the area. At number one, we have Latte Hotel Soul. Latte Hotel Soul is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to experience luxury right in the heart of the city. With its prime location near Yuljiro Wong subway station and the bustling Mongdong area, guests have easy access to shopping, dining, and entertainment. The hotel boasts a whopping 10 dining options serving everything from French to local specialties, so food lovers will definitely be in heaven. Plus, the modern rooms come with all the comforts you could need, like an LCD TV, mini bar, and even plush bathroes. After a day of exploring, guests can unwind at the indoor pool or indulge in some relaxation at the spa. What really sets Lot Hotel Soul apart is its blend of luxury and convenience. The stunning views of the city from the rooms add a special touch, and the fitness center is perfect for those who want to keep up their workout routine while traveling. For those looking to explore further, the hotel offers a tour desk to help arrange day trips, making it easy to experience all that Seoul has to offer. With its combination of great amenities, delicious dining options, and a location that puts guests right in the action, Lot Hotel Soul is definitely a top pick for anyone visiting the city. Deciding whether to visit this city is a personal choice, but there are a few factors to consider that might help you make up your mind. This city offers a unique blend of culture, history, and modern attractions that appeal to a wide range of travelers. Whether you're interested in exploring historical landmarks, indulging in local cuisine, or simply soaking in the atmosphere of a new place, this city has something to offer. For those who appreciate the finer things in life, the city's top tier hotels provide luxurious accommodations, exceptional service, and breathtaking views. But beyond the hotels, it's the city's charm that really leaves a lasting impression. From its vibrant neighborhoods to its scenic parks, this city is more than just a destination. It's an experience. Before you book your trip, consider what kind of traveler you are. If you're someone who enjoys discovering new cultures, meeting friendly locals, and uncovering hidden gems, then this city should definitely be on your list. On the other hand, if you prefer more tranquil, off-the-beaten path destinations, it might be worth exploring some alternatives. In the end, whether or not you should visit this city depends on your personal travel goals. If you're looking for a dynamic, exciting city with plenty to see and do, then this city might just be the perfect destination for your next adventure. So, there you have it. Hi. Welcome to Aloft Seoul Gangnam. The property is located in Seoul’s upscale  Gangnam district known for luxury shopping, beauty clinics, and nightlife. Aloft Seoul  Gangnam is directly South of the Han River, less than a mile from Starfield COEX Mall, and  about 2.5 miles from Lotte World Mall. The hotel opened in 2014 and has 188 rooms, including  4 suites, across 15 floors. Aloft hotels are intended to be a budget-friendly version of W  Hotels with bold design and a fun, casual vibe. This is the lobby. The back wall is colorful  and creates an energetic atmosphere especially at night. To the left is a seating area with  equally colorful chairs and couch. Tucked away in the corner near the entrance is an interactive map  and a business center with a computer and printer. Opposite the seating area is the front desk which  is named the Aloha desk. Turning the corner, we have a hallway with elevators, a public bathroom,  and Re:fuel, a hybrid cafe and convenience store. Re:fuel is open daily and serves coffee,  smoothies, chilled soft drinks, wine, snacks, and casual foods like sandwiches and pizza.  Outside is a garden area with tables and chairs. Heading back into the hotel, this is another view  of Re:fuel. On the left is a display of wines and snacks for sale. Heading over to the elevators,  we will go up to the 14th floor for our room tour. This is a Chic River room. Next to the door are  light control buttons and a slot for the room key to power the room. On the right is the bathroom.  There is a single sink vanity and a walk-in shower with a main shower head and a handheld shower  head. Bath products are by Drybar. Lastly, there is an advanced toilet. Opposite the bathroom is  a closet space with robes, clothes hangers, iron, ironing board, shoe horn, and indoor slippers.  Moving the sliding door reveals a counter with a coffee machine, water boiler, and snacks for sale.  The drawers have the New Testament in Korean, a laundry bag, and a safe. Below is some storage  space and a small mini fridge with some drinks for sale and a little space if you want to refrigerate  something. To the right is the bedroom with a TV embedded in the wall, a king sized bed, two night  stands, and a nice cityscape mural above the bed. Along the back wall is a desk, red chair, bench,  and two floor-to-ceiling windows. This is the view of a neighborhood park and the Han River from the  14th floor. Another view of the Chic River room. Two things to point out: the rooms do not have USB  outlets so pack accordingly and per Korean law, hotels with more than 50 rooms cannot provide  free toiletries so dental kits are for sale. Moving down to the 3rd floor we have Re:charge,  the hotel’s gym which is always open. On the left is a rack of dumbbells and some benches.  Along the back wall are ellipticals, stationary bikes, and treadmills. On  the right side are yoga mats and water. This is the 2nd floor which has Tactic, a  conference room, and a public bathroom on the right and a bar and a restaurant on the  left. This is W xyz Bar, a nod to W Hotels, open every evening from 5pm to midnight. Adjacent  to the bar is Artichoke, the property’s restaurant which serves a breakfast buffet, and a la  carte lunch and dinner. The breakfast buffet costs ₩ 27,000 per person or is complimentary for  those with Marriott Platinum status or higher. The breakfast buffet had chilled fruit, pastries,  coffee, juice, salad, cold meats, pickled fruit, pasta, meatballs, eggs, fried rice, pumpkin,  breakfast meats, and the last dish changes daily. Pictured is fried chicken and french fries.  Other days they had fish and beef bulgogi. Ok. Time for ratings. I give the Chic River  room a 3.5. Although the room was on the small side at 258 sq ft, the room was modern,  colorful, had a clean and functional bathroom, comfortable bed and bench, a wall-mounted TV,  and a view of the Han River. I give the amenities a 3. Aloft Seoul Gangnam has a restaurant, W  xyz bar, a cafe, a gym, and two seating areas in the lobby and the garden in back. I give the  intangibles a 3.5. Service was good. Dante, Kacey, and manager Celine were all very friendly and  helpful. The location is kind of a mixed bag as it is in a popular district, Gangnam, but it felt  oddly distant from points of interest because the useful bus stop is across a busy street or just  far enough to make walking a bit inconvenient. Aloft Seoul Gangnam gets an extra intangible  point from me because of its unique, colorful design. I am a big fan of Aloft and W Hotels’  unique styling. Cash prices for the Chic River room are typically $185 per night. At that price,  I give a 3 for cash value which represents some value. I would tell people to consider booking if  they like the modern rooms and the location. The Chic River room is not bookable with Marriott  points so I cannot give a points value rating. However, the base Aloft Urban room can be  booked with Marriott points. This room type is identical in layout to the Chic River room  but is on a lower floor and does not have a view of the Han River. Cash prices for  the base room are usually around $150 per night or 25,000 Marriott points per night.  I give a 3 for cash value and points value which represents some value. For those  with Marriott Platinum status or higher, I would bump those value ratings up to  4 representing good value because of the free daily breakfast buffet for two benefit  which would otherwise cost about $40 per day. In summary, Aloft Seoul Gangnam is a  vibrant hotel in the upscale Gangnam district with a restaurant, a bar, social spaces, and small but modern rooms at a fair price.  Their colorful design and lighting creates a fun, hip environment. Ok. That is all for my review  of Aloft Seoul Gangnam. Thanks for joining.

Dignitaries from around the world Recently, a hotspot for Middle East VVIPs What's a suite worth 20M won a night like? Plus, the ultimate new staycation lounge and a massive subscriber event with a 5-star stay What's up guys! It's DDN. VVIPs consider facilities and prestige along with security and the hotel's location. One preferred hotel among state guests is Lotte Hotel at Sogong-dong. The Lotte Hotel Executive Tower Its top room costs over 20M won a night, the Royal Suite. Shall we first take a look at this unseen suite? The suite's living room is as grand as a hotel lobby, vast and majestic. Exemplifying Lotte's European luxury, it's the essence of their offering. The beige-toned living room is bright and warm accented with gold tones for an upscale look. Decorated with Korean ceramics and props for a touch of Korean beauty. The unique chandelier stands out. A hotel's chandelier often shows how much care has gone into a room. True to Lotte's top suites, every space has unique and luxurious chandeliers. Not just a separate bar but also a dining area for nine and a Bechstein piano in the living area perfect for private parties or events. Bedroom with stunning Namsan view features a blend of splendid yet serene gold tones with Eastern beauty. Lotte's famous beds, you know? Mattress co-developed with Simmons a super-premium bedding system. Lotte's proud He:on bedding and covers by Italy's 120-year Gastaldi. Dressed for ultimate luxury and perfect sleep for busy dignitaries, providing the best sleep environment. Lotte Hotel Executive Tower is not only famous among state guests but also well-known among staycation enthusiasts. Unmatched 'stay & dine' experience It's known for top-notch dining lounges. I praised 'Le Salon' two years ago with my own paid-for review video. While others cut lounge services Lotte Hotel Seoul opens 'La Cime' upping their service game. Unlike 'Le Salon' on the 16th floor the new 'La Cime' is on the top floor situated on the 34th floor. Its name 'La Cime' means 'the top' in French, fitting its location. Entering 'La Cime', you're greeted with luxurious gold tones and patterns featuring artist Park Sun-ki's work. An art of charcoal signifying purification. 'La Cime's' entry offers an open view. View Euljiro and Gwanghwamun's skylines and distant Inwangsan through one window. Namsan feels close through the opposite. Lotte wasn't known for Namsan views but now, it's a top pick for many views of Namsan from high floors are stunningly close and impressive. 'La Cime', like 'Le Salon', has touches of Korean design that's welcoming. Modern lighting and private room spaces A lounge fitting for top-tier guests exuding luxury and sophistication. 'La Cime' excels in its food offerings worthy of Korea's top hotel title. Offering afternoon tea, happy hour, and breakfast three times of service provided. Afternoon tea available post-check-in with a two-tiered tray of scones and various desserts served with tea. Desserts are as tasty as they look. Beyond the tray, macarons and cookies and rare date palms are also offered. Enjoy these with 'La Cime' special latte. Enough to be a full meal with desserts alone. Happy hour after 6 PM provides quality variety reminiscent of 'La Seine' with a range of high-quality dishes. The meat quality is especially important. Unbelievably high standard for lounge with quality lamb and tenderloin steaks ready. Beyond meat, a full spread of hot food including pasta and shrimp dishes. On the other side, salmon and cheese salad a variety of cold cuts are available. For dessert, various breads and cakes plus macarons and fruit are prepared. You see why it's top for 'eat-cations'. 'La Cime' also features a central bar. With cocktails crafted by experts the signature cocktails are memorable. During happy hour, table service with finger food and signature drinks. 'Mugunghwa's Sunset' filled with Seoul's glow and a drink inspired by the refreshing waterfall show 'Deep Island' offered at the Peninsula Lounge on the first floor. Champagne 'Le Marquis de Marillac Brut' various wines and whiskeys ready for you with finely prepared round ice balls. Breakfast as diverse as the happy hour. Hearty meat dishes even in the morning made-to-order egg dishes and yoghurt, desserts, and fruit. Yeah… I’m pretty sure no one  actually swims in this pool. Hi. Welcome to JW Marriott Dongdaemun  Square Seoul. This property is under Marriott’s flagship brand, JW  Marriott, and is located across the street from Heunginjimun which is a  restored gate of Seoul’s fortress wall. JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square Seoul is a modern  luxury hotel that opened in 2013 with 170 rooms and 15 suites across 11 floors. This revolving  door rotates very slowly, but it gives you time to take notice of JW’s griffin logo. There are  normal doors next to this, if you want to enter and exit the hotel more quickly. This is the  lobby, which is incredibly well-lit thanks to the floor to ceiling glass windows. On the left  are two sets of elevators and a griffin statue. This is the front desk area. Notice the marble  reception desks and floors, very opulent. Adjacent to the front desk area is  The Lounge which offers afternoon tea service and dinner and drinks in the  evening, with a great view of Heunginjimun. This is a 1 King Bed, Skyview Room. A really  cool feature in this hotel is that your room key activates your room. This is double-edged  as it makes it easier to leave your key in your room and lock yourself out. Along the hallway are  some closets. Here are the robes. This top drawer has a safe, the other drawers are for storage.  Here is the living room and bedroom. It is a bit tight but there is a lot to unpack here.  There is a water boiler, Nespresso machine, and water bottles. This drawer contains tea and  Nespresso pods. The lower drawer has drinkware. This mini fridge has a minibar and space to chill  your drinks - very useful. Most people would miss this, but behind this panel is more drinkware  and another minibar. Another view of the room, there is a king size bed, two small sofas, a  table, and a TV. This is our view of Dongdaemun. This handy little remote controls the  sheers and blinds in the Skyview room. This feature is the Skyview room’s  upgraded benefit over a base room. The bedside control panel has light controls  and only one USB port, definitely lacking on ports. I think it would’ve been better to  have one traditional outlet than only one USB. Moving over to the bathroom, everything is marble  which is luxurious. This is the bathtub. This is the sink area. Notice the hanging mirror and  that you can see the hallway from the bathroom. This part of the counter lifts up to reveal  toiletries, hair dryer and hair straightener, and a mirror. Nice, Aromatherapy products.  My wife will happily load up on these. There is a TV in the bathroom.  There is a bit of a lag to turn on. It swivels so you can continue watching  your kdrama while in the bathtub. Hi. There is a bidet toilet in the corner,  along with a phone and an emergency call button. This is the shower. It has both an adjustable  shower head and a rainfall shower head. The body wash and shampoo  are made by Aromatherapy. Outside of the sliding door is the  entryway. Before leaving the room, guests with Marriott Platinum status or  higher can choose from a list of drinks and desserts as a welcome amenity - we chose  strawberry ice cream and a half bottle of wine. Entering on the eighth floor, then walking  down some stairs, this is the pool floor. And this is the most glamorous pool you  will likely ever see. Let’s admire the pool and the chandeliers from all angles, shall we?  Yeah… I’m pretty sure no one actually swims in this pool. But if you do, it is heated and there  is always a lifeguard on duty. There are some pool chairs on the side, right next to a marble  fireplace - you know, typical swimming pool decor. Looks like an equally glamorous  jacuzzi with some more lounge chairs. And one more view of the super  fancy swimming pool and chandeliers. On the 10th floor, is the Executive Lounge. Lounge access can be purchased when booking  a standard room but is complimentary when booking suites or for those with Marriott Platinum  status or higher. Over here we have two computers. Around the wall, there are some couches and  lounge chairs. I like the room dividers, they are strategically placed and really  increase the amount of privacy in the lounge. Nice, they have chess sets. This is the food area. Drinks and  coffee are available all day. Dinner and cocktails are served between 5- 7pm.  They serve breakfast and lunch as well. They had an open, self-serve bar which looked like  this and was interesting since you usually see a bartender but this version definitely saves money  for the hotel. There is more seating back here. There is an outdoor patio with some more  seating and a great view of Dongdaemun. This door leads right back to  the food and self-serve bar area. This is Tavolo 24, the hotel’s buffet.  Pricing varies by meal. Complimentary breakfast for two is a benefit for those  with Marriott Platinum status or higher. At the entrance are pancakes and a salad  bar. Coffee machines are along the wall. Here are chilled juices and ice  cream. More juices in the fridge. In the center, there are wines  from different countries for sale. Over here we have smoked salmon, behind which is a counter for samgyupsal  and lettuce. On the island are pastries. On the back counter, there are hash  browns, potatoes, sausage, and bacon. This is an omelet station. There are  cereals. This island has oatmeal. More seating and the view. This station in the  back of the buffet has Korean and Japanese food, at least during breakfast. There were two types  of kimchi, edamame, tofu salad, and natto. Around the corner, more kimchi,  braised fish, and takoyaki. On other mornings, this station had sashimi,  just not on the day I film. And some veggies. On the same floor and across the  elevators, there is BLT Steak, the hotel’s steakhouse restaurant which is open  for lunch and dinner. On the 11th and top floor, is The Griffin, the hotel’s rooftop bar which  offers unobstructed views of Dongdaemun. On the lower level is Seoul Baking Company.  There are chilled drinks and fruit in the fridge. They sell desserts, wine,  sandwiches, and pastries. Exiting this door leads directly to the  subway which is incredibly convenient for getting around Seoul. Oh, as one last  reminder of how luxurious this hotel is, this is the men’s public  bathroom on the lower level. Rating time. I give the skyview room 4 out of 5  for its functionality, marble bathroom, the cool hidden compartments, and of course, the skyview  windows. The main drawbacks were the lack of outlets and space. I think the baseroom, without  the skyview windows, would be a 3 out of 5 though. For the amenities, I have to give  a 3 out of 5. Even though the pool, the rooftop bar, the executive lounge, and  the restaurants were of very high quality, this hotel was missing some common amenities such  as a gym and spa. When I asked about the gym, spa, and golf simulator amenities listed on the  hotel’s website, multiple staff told me that access was prohibited which seemed odd.  After the trip, there was a note on the website saying these facilities may be closed  due to government restriction, but staff never mentioned those restrictions during our stay.  Whatever the case, with the addition of a gym, spa, and golf simulator, the amenities  rating would easily be a 4, maybe even a 5. For intangibles, JW Marriott easily scores a  5 out of 5. Their location is convenient and their service is excellent. Within a block of  the property, is a lot of shopping, dining, and Dongdaemun Design Plaza. Walking out of the lower  level leads directly to the subway which is super convenient. The staff were helpful, they helped  us hail taxis and secured a dinner reservation at Viking’s Wharf, a coveted seafood buffet, and at  an art gallery. The staff were fluent in English which was helpful and makes sense given their  international clientele. We noticed the maids left us water bottles and two chocolates every  day during room cleaning. Much appreciated. For cash value, when we booked in September 2022,  room rates for the skyview room were about $400 per night. At that price, I would have to give  a 2 out of 5 - little value given the lack of amenities, you’d essentially be paying for the  room and the pool. If the gym, spa, and golf simulator were available, then maybe a 3 out of 5.  Or if you are Marriott Platinum or higher, a 3 out of 5 since you would have complimentary access to  the Executive Lounge and Tavolo 24 for breakfast. For points value, award nights were going  for about 47,000 Marriott points per night at which I would give a 4 out of 5. This  is a good redemption. I would recommend booking with points, and remember  Marriott gives the 5th night free when you book 5 consecutive award nights  - even better value, this is what we did. In summary, JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square  Seoul is a modern luxury hotel with high quality amenities. I recommend booking  with points. The value proposition isn’t as strong when booking with cash unless you  have Marriott Platinum status or higher, or until all of the amenities  are available. That is all for my review of the JW Marriott Dongdaemun  Square Seoul. Thanks for joining.

Hello everyone, I’m heading to Seoul, South Korea, which is my home city, and I am going to stay at the Lotte Hotel Seoul. So, I will share my room tour video with you today. Let’s get started. There are two different buildings in Lotte Hotel Seoul one is the Main Tower, and the other one is the Executive Tower, which is higher-end and pricier. I am going to stay in the Executive Tower. There are some liquors as well as coffee and tea. The tea is from Osulloc, a premium tea brand from Jeju Island, Korea. There are also some wine glasses, coffee cups, and wine. In the drawer, there are some snacks, toothbrushes, and toothpaste available for an extra charge. In the small refrigerator, there are some sodas, water, and champagne. They provide two bottles of water every day during your stay. Beside the bed, there are lighting control buttons, a USB port, and a power outlet. The closet seems a bit smaller than I expected I found it wasn’t enough to store all my clothing. Also, there is a small safe right here. The bathroom was clean. You can open the blind to see into the room or close it for privacy. Robes and slippers were provided as well. The living room wasn’t that big considering the price range, but the Seoul city view was amazing. One thing I found inconvenient is that you pay extra for staying in the Executive Tower, but all other amenities are in the Main Tower. Therefore, you had to walk all the way to the Main Tower to enjoy the other facilities. There is a gym, golf driving range, and swimming pool. The main reason I stayed in this hotel is because of the location. It is very close to the subway station. Also, right beside the hotel, there is the Lotte Department Store, where you can enjoy tax-free shopping. You can also walk to Myeongdong Street, a famous shopping and eating street in Seoul, and it is very close to the palace, where you can explore traditional Korean culture. I am going to leave the website link in the description box below. I hope my video is helpful. Thanks so much for watching, and I will see you in my next video. Bye!
